DOC.TI: Podcast interviews Fat Boy Chronicles author
DOC.TEXT: Featured in this weeks podcast, Kids Beating Obesity, is the story of young teenager Jimmy Winterpock and his incredible journey as an overweight youngster dealing with the horrors of being picked on, made fun of and bullied. Our guest is Michael Buchanan, co-author of the book The Fat Boy Chronicles, and writer of the screenplay for the full-length movie of the same name. The story really hits home with the constant reminder of yet another part of the childhood obesity nightmare not just all the health risks and problems like high blood pressure, diabetes, muscle and joint problems but the bullying and psychological side. Inspired by a true story, The Fat Boy Chronicles offers Jimmys school journal taking us into his daily thoughts and actions through a school term. This book and movie is most definitely something both kids and their parents should make a priority. Mike Buchanan and co-author Diane Lang are former teachers, and they bring great insight into this powerful story. By the way, highlights of some past podcasts of Kids Beating Obesity featuring guests in the physical education field is available in the show previous to our interview with Mike Buchanan. Get access to all of the podcasts, check topics and bios of all guests, by going to , click new media, Kids Beating Obesity. Lets get some emails: Gerry, Plainfield: My son and I saw you at new Balance Naperville at your foot screening to check his flat feet. At 13 years old, he is 25 pounds overweight, and his feet and knees hurt. Are these factors related? Dr. Weil: Yes they are. Excessive weight will aggravate all the joints of the lower extremities. Orthotics can reduce the flat foot-related foot and knee stress, but the added weight makes things worse. Steve, Naperville: My 15-year-old daughter is a serious club tennis player who is always dealing with shin splints. Her physical therapist mentioned orthotics. Would they help? Dr. Weil: Absolutely most persistent lower leg shin problems are foot mechanics related (go to Nov. 10, 2009, article common place shin pain is treatable at sportsdoctorradio.com/newspaper articles). Orthotics and foot, lower leg muscle strengthening exercises will make a difference. Call me with questions. Dr. Robert A. Weil is a sports podiatrist with an office in Aurora. You can hear him on his weekly radio show at 6:30 p.m. Thursdays on 90.9 FM. Visit his website at and contact him at drrweilsportsdoctor@yahoo.com

DOC.TI: ProActive Kids program has kids on road to health
DOC.TEXT: These days when 9-year-old Bryson Taylor reaches for an afternoon snack, its more likely to be a bunch of grapes than the bag of potato chips he would have picked just weeks ago, his mom, Jenny, says. This is just one of several healthy changes that Bryson and his family have made since January when he started the free, eight-week ProActive Kids (PAK) program at the Edward Health & Fitness Center (EHFC) in Woodridge. Weve also been shopping for resistance bands, and we hope to buy a treadmill in the near future, Jenny says. The PAK Foundation, whose mission is to reduce childhood obesity, one community at a time, also offers the program in Wheaton where the organization has headquarters PAK partners with organizations, such as Edward Hospital, to deliver the program, which is designed for kids 8 to 14 years old who struggle with unhealthy weight. Partnering with ProActive Kids appealed to us because it focuses on kids, and its comprehensive, says Cheryl Eck, Edwards director of E-Health. Unlike a lot of programs that only cover diet and exercise, PAK also addresses social and emotional issues that can get in the way of developing healthier habits. PAK at EHFC meets from 4 to 5:30 p.m. on Monday and Wednesday, and from 4 to 6 p.m. on Friday. On each of these days, a PAK-certified personal trainer leads a 45-minute fitness class to increase muscular strength, cardiovascular endurance and flexibility. In another segment, a registered dietitian from Edward takes the kids through nutrition basics. We now all read labels in the grocery store, Jenny says. Another key member of the team is a licensed professional counselor from Linden Oaks at Edward. She leads discussions and fun activities that promote self-esteem and good coping techniques such as how to handle bullying. Participants parents and siblings are invited to attend the Friday sessions, so they too can benefit from the program. This also helps them provide long-term support to the child whos enrolled. On Fridays the families complete two exercise circuits and some stretches, and theres usually a review of that weeks nutrition sessions, Jenny says. There also might be activities with the therapist. One week Brysons group broke up into pairs, and each person wrote something they liked about their partner and vice versa. Then each family did the same thing. My son looks forward to the program, and his body fat is down 3.4 percent, Jenny says. His fat mass also is down 1.5 percent, and his fat free mass is up 4.5 percent, which means more muscle. As I told Bryson, we see this as an opportunity to build a good foundation for the future. Its more about lifestyle than losing weight. And he even gets a side benefit of extra training for the upcoming soccer season. A physician referral is required for children to participate in the program. The spring session of PAK at EHFC runs April 2 through May 25. To enroll, call 630-681-1558 or visit to learn more. Health Aware is courtesy of Edward Hospital

DOC.TI: Media Lifeline: Boris Johnson
DOC.TEXT: It seems the Twittersphere is one of the key battlegrounds in this year's London Mayor elections. December 2009 ... Boris Johnson is rapped by the Greater London Authority's standards committee for using his official Mayor of London Twitter feed to celebrate The Sun's decision to back the Tory Party in the forthcoming General Election. 19 March 2012 ... But has he learned his lesson? As campaigning for the 2012 mayoral election begins in earnest, the official @mayoroflondon Twitter account mysteriously morphs overnight into @borisjohnson. At a stroke, Johnson's Twitter campaign acquires more than 250,000 followers - and the account's weblink is changed from to . 20 March 2012 ... His election rivals, including Ken Livingstone, are outraged. A member of Livingstone's campaign team delivers a blistering indictment: 'Basically, taxpayers' money has been spent to build up and maintain a feed that Boris has now hijacked.' 21 March 2012 ... Johnson's team had initially defended his actions, claiming that the account is owned by Twitter, not the taxpayer, and that it was his 'brand' and personality that had attracted followers to the site in the first place. Then a post on Johnson's campaign website claims that, with regard to Twitter, he has been acting all along in the interests of openness and honesty - and he is mystified by all the hysteria Strangely, though, this post is now deleted. 22 March 2012 ... Johnson, who'd set up @backboris2012, then returns all the followers he'd seized to @mayoroflondon, mothballs @borisjohnson and gets down to serious campaigning. 'Boris meets commuters at Wimbledon station,' @backboris2012 crows; 'I'm launching the fare deal express,' @ken4london responds. Brian Paddick waits a day to Tweet the devastating: 'With members of the Barking Gospel Oak User Group in Haringey this morning.' Fast forward ... 2 May 2012: During the campaign, @backboris2012 had been flooding the social media space with pictures of Johnson pestering commuters at Wimbledon station; and @ken4london had responded with an endless stream of pictures of the Livingstone battlebus going round and round the Elephant and Castle roundabout. But now @brianpaddick lands a critical blow. 'Hello. Hope everyone is enjoying the lovely weather,' he Tweets. -------------------- Did you find this article useful? DOC.TI: The one-cent solution
DOC.TEXT: OTTAWA -- Canada is scrapping the penny, ending production this year of a coin that weighs down consumers' pockets while adding little to their purchasing power. The government announced in Thursday's federal budget that it will shortly jettison the one-cent coin a casualty of Ottawa's drive for efficiency and thrift. It costs taxpayers a penny-and-a-half every time we make one, Finance Minister Jim Flaherty told the Commons, adding the move will save taxpayers $11-million annually. Mr. Flaherty, whose department described the penny as a nuisance in budget documents, said the 2.35-gram coin is now more trouble than it's worth. Pennies take up too much space on our dressers at home, Mr. Flaherty added. They take up far too much time for small businesses trying to grow and create jobs. The last one-cent coin will be minted this April, ending what federal officials say is close to 150 years of Canadian penny production. The Royal Canadian Mint will stop distributing pennies to financial institutions in the fall of 2012 and the government will work to withdraw one-cent coins from circulation. The increasing scarcity of pennies means Canadians will have to get used to cash transactions being rounded off if they've got no pennies on hand. Ottawa is suggesting businesses round off cash transactions to the nearest five-cent increment but says it's leaving this to businesses to work out for themselves. This rounding off would occur after taxes had been applied to the purchase and would not be necessary for credit or debit transactions. Retailers and restaurateurs, however, are urging Ottawa to clearly explain to Canadians what is happening to cash transactions so customers don't feel they're getting ripped off and that there's a level playing field for all businesses. Not everyone is relieved to see the one-cent coin abolished. As a coin collector, it's a black day because the penny has been such an integral part of Canadian history. When Canada was young, a penny was a lot of money, said Brian Grant Duff with All Nations Stamp and Coin in Vancouver. He predicted the five-cent coin's days are now numbered too. The Royal Canadian Mint produced 660 million pennies in 2011, federal officials said. The Canadian government is hardly alone in scrapping the penny. Federal officials said they could count at least 17 other countries that have ceased production of low-denomination coins over the past four decades. The Harper government says savings for business and consumers will vastly exceed what Ottawa recoups by killing the penny. A study by one Canadian financial institution, Desjardins Group, estimates the economic costs of the penny for the private sector total $150-million annually. This includes counting, storing and transporting the coins. Ottawa says it won't be policing consumer-business transactions, but added that businesses are expected to round prices in a fair, consistent and transparent manner. It couldn't guarantee consumers would be better off but cited a 2005 Bank of Canada study that concluded the inflationary impact of eliminating the penny would be small or non-existent. The government had no estimates Thursday on how many pennies remain in circulation, including those piling up in jars or cans. It noted that the study by Desjardins Group estimates Canadians could be hoarding several billion pennies. Federal officials said more than 35 billion pennies have been minted in Canada in the past 104 years. This, they noted Thursday, would weigh 94 million kilograms or as much as 1,500 Leopard 2 tanks. The federal government says it will encourage charities to collect pennies from Canadians and redeem them through banks and the mint as a fundraising venture.

DOC.TI: Strong proponent of breastfeeding
DOC.TEXT: AURORA Since the 1980s, Rush-Copley Hospital has helped new mothers master the art of breastfeeding their babies. Now a $33,700 grant from the March of Dimes Illinois chapter will help the hospital hire experienced breastfeeding moms to help patients in its lactation center. Were very grateful to the March of Dimes for giving us the opportunity to expand our lactation services, said Jennifer Toerpe, director of Rush-Copleys Womens Health Institute. Its so important for us to support breastfeeding in Kane and Kendall counties. The March of Dimes primary goal is preventing premature births. The longer a mother breastfeeds, the better her chances for well-spaced pregnancies, which also decreases her risk of preterm deliveries, said Dr. Victoria Nichols Johnson, a member of the March of Dimes Illinois Chapter Program Services Committee. Other benefits include a decreased risk of breast and ovarian cancer, and more rapid postpartum weight loss. Medical associations throughout the U.S. agree that feeding babies nothing but breast milk for six to 12 months gives them lifelong health benefits, Toerpe said. Breastfeeding supports weight gain and brain development. It gives babies immunity against diseases and helps them bond with their mothers, she said. Babies that dont breastfeed have increased risk of obesity, allergies and heart disease. For that reason, the Healthy People 2020 program has set a goal that at least 80 percent of mothers try breastfeeding and at least 60 percent of them breastfeed exclusively for six months or more. But many women choose never to breastfeed their babies, or to stop breastfeeding after a few weeks, for a number of reasons, Toerpe said. Sometimes they stop because they must return to work and cant pump breast milk at their jobs. Sometimes they give up on breastfeeding after having trouble or pain with it. Sometimes they refuse to breastfeed because they want to preserve their pre-pregnancy figures, or because they grew up believing that only poor or rural people dont use formula. There are many cultural and societal influences that lead women not to breastfeed their babies, Toerpe said. Some say that its not natural or that they dont want to do it in public. Teens and older moms are less likely to breastfeed because they usually cant stay home with their babies as long as women in their 20s and 30s can. Several years ago Rush-Copley stopped giving formula samples to new mothers who give birth there. Instead, a lactation specialist gives them information about the differences between breast milk and formula, as well as advice and instructions about how to make sure their babies are breastfeeding properly. It was so helpful to have the lactation consultants working with latching the baby and showing me what to do, said Jenny Searls, who recently gave birth to a boy at Rush-Copley. They were so kind and positive, and really wanted me to succeed. I really felt like I was part of a team vs. being on my own. The lactation center also offers community education classes on breastfeeding, outpatient consultations and free baby weight checks as well as free or reduced-cost rentals of breast pumps. While the percentage of Rush-Copleys maternity patients who breastfeed has fallen from just more than 90 percent to 86 percent in the past few years, the hospital still boasts one of the best breastfeeding rates in the state, Toerpe said. Several new programs that the March of Dimes grant will pay for could boost the percentage back over 90 percent, she added. The first step will be hiring two peer counselors experienced breastfeeding mothers who can relate to new moms struggling with breastfeeding as equals rather than medical figures. The peer counselors also will visit medical clinics throughout the Aurora area to enlist obstetricians, pediatricians and family practitioners in the quest to support breastfeeding as a parenting choice. The peer counselors should be on staff by the end of March, Toerpe said. Grant money also will fund new brochures about breastfeeding; a tracking program to find out how many patients continue breastfeeding for six months or longer; and interconception care for women who are not yet pregnant but who plan to be soon. Healthier women are more likely to breastfeed than women with chronic health issues like obesity, diabetes or heart disease, Toerpe said. These types of care are in line with the March of Dimes mission the reason the hospital received the grant. Rush-Copley was selected for their innovation, multidisciplinary approach, and ability to infuse components of interconception care education and the benefits of breastfeeding, said Shelly Musser, associate state director for March of Dimes Program Services and Public Affairs. Interconception care is care that a woman gets between pregnancies, which can help lower risk and promote wellness among women of childbearing age. The program expansion this years money will fund will continue next year, even if the March of Dimes does not renew the grant, Toerpe said. Weve always been a strong proponent of breastfeeding, she said. As the fourth-largest maternity center in the state, located in the second-largest city in the state, we need to keep promoting breastfeeding for the health of our community.

DOC.TI: Cellmid Launches volis Hair Products
DOC.TEXT: The first clinically validated hair growth product to be released in over two decades Cellmid Limited (ASX: CDY) advises that it has commenced the commercial launch of its Evolis(TM) hair growth products with an event in Sydney for representatives of the national printed and electronic media yesterday. The products have received celebrity endorsement from Paula Duncan, AM. The press release for the event can be accessed here. In February 2012 Cellmid advised that it had received TGA approval and expected completion of the GMP manufacture and commercial launch of the Evolis(TM) products in May 2012. These events have now been brought forward and commercial sale of the products through pharmacies is likely to commence in the middle of the calendar year, three months earlier than previously planned. The Evolis(TM) for Men and Evolis(TM) for Women products have important TGA approved claims of "promotes hair growth", "helps prevent hair loss and thinning" and "restores the natural hair growth cycle". The Evolis(TM) products will not require a prescription and will be sold as over the counter medicines in individual pharmacies as well as pharmacy chains at the recommended retail price of $89 for each 50 ml bottle. The Company is targeting a minimum of 400 pharmacies nationally within the first twelve months. It is estimated that 40% of women and 50% of men in western countries are affected by hair loss at some stage in their life. Current hair growth products either have serious side effects or lack evidence of efficacy. The key competitive advantage for the Evolis(TM) range is safety combined with efficacy and as such the products represent a significant market opportunity. Cellmid, via its wholly owned subsidiary Advangen International Pty Ltd, holds exclusive manufacturing and distribution rights for the products in Australia, USA, Europe, India and South America with significant combined sales potential. Commercial launch outside Australia is expected to commence in late 2012. The website for the Evolis(TM) products will be re-launched on 15th April 2012 with a commercial interface to facilitate internet sales and a promotional video which will also be released on site in participating pharmacies. About Cellmid Limited (ASX: CDY) Cellmid is an Australian biotechnology company developing innovative novel therapies and diagnostic tests for inflammatory diseases, heart attack and cancer. Cellmid holds the largest and most comprehensive portfolio of intellectual property related to midkine and midkine antagonists globally. The Company's most advanced clinical development program is for the treatment of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) utilising the midkine protein. Cellmid is also developing anti-midkine antibodies for the treatment of inflammatory and autoimmune disorders. In addition, Cellmid is commercialising midkine as a biomarker for cancer diagnosis. Elevated midkine concentration in the blood and other body fluids is strongly indicative of cancer. Cellmid's first product, the MK-ELISA, is a blood test that sensitively and accurately measures serum midkine levels. About Advangen International Pty Ltd Advangen International Pty Ltd is the wholly owned subsidiary of Cellmid Limited. Advangen develops and sells scientifically validated products to prevent and treat various forms of hair loss. The company's products have well understood mechanism of action and have been extensively tested for safety and efficacy with published validation data. Advangen has two market ready product ranges, one for pharmacies (Evolis(TM)) and one for professional hair salons (Jo-Ju(TM) and Lexilis(TM)). In addition, the company is developing midkine in a high performance formulation for the treatment of age related hair loss. About Advangen's Products Advangen's products are based on using FGF-5 (Fibroblast Growth Factor 5) inhibitors to prevent hair loss, extend the growth phase of the hair cycle and activate resting follicles prompting them to grow. FGF-5 is known to cause hair to fall out and suppress hair growth. Its absence results in strong hair growth. FGF-5 has no other functions rendering its inhibitors safe. Advangen's FGF-5 inhibitor products are plant extracts that have been tested for their ability to inhibit FGF-5 with propriety high through put assay. Several products have been developed, of which the Advangen range (Jo-Ju(TM) and Lexilis(TM)) will be sold through hair salons as cosmeceuticals. The Evolis(TM) range has been registered by the TGA as a listed medicine and will be sold as an over the counter product in pharmacies. DOC.TI: DIABETES: Gliptins backed for diabetes second line
DOC.TEXT:
Meta-analysis suggests gliptins have benefits over sulphonylureas By David Swan Gliptins should be used more widely in patients with diabetes as they are associated with less weight gain and fewer hypoglycaemic episodes than sulphonylureas, say researchers. A meta-analysis of 27 studies found both gliptins and incretins appeared to have benefits for weight loss over the older sulphonylureas and pioglitazone, in findings that could lead to a rewrite of the NICE algorithm for diabetes treatment. NICE guidelines currently suggest using metformin first line and gliptins as alternatives to using sulphonylureas second line, but only if there is a considerable risk of hypoglycaemia or sulphonylureas are contraindicated or not tolerated. The recommendation is based on studies carried out before 2009. The authors of the new meta-analysis found current evidence suggests gliptins should be used as a routine second-line treatment to metformin and that incretins might be suitable for patients targeting weight loss. The international group of researchers looked at randomised controlled trials of diabetes treatments involving 7,100 adults and found adding gliptins to metformin lowered HbA1c in a similar way to sulphonylureas and glitazones, with mean differences between groups of 0.07% and 0.09%. But patients taking gliptins and metformin gained less weight than those who were given sulphonylureas or glitazones with metformin, with differences between groups of -1.92kg and -2.96kg respectively. In most trials comparing gliptins with sulphonylureas as add-on therapy to metformin, the risk of hypoglycaemia was higher in the group treated with a sulphonylurea. Study leader Professor David Matthews, professor of diabetic medicine at the University of Oxford, said gliptins were a `good alternative' to older treatments: `DPP-4 inhibitors [gliptins] can be used as second- line treatment in patients with type 2 diabetes who do not achieve their glycaemic targets with metformin alone. But questions about their long-term safety still remain to be answered from ongoing trials.' He also pointed out the data did not include cost comparisons and that it suggested incretins might be even more powerful than gliptins when added to metformin: `For reductions in both HbA1c and body weight, our analysis suggests that GLP-1 agonists seem to have an advantage over DPP-4 inhibitors.' Dr Colin Kenny, a GP in County Down and a committee member of the Primary Care Diabetes Society, said the study should help GPs to prescribe gliptins according to the latest evidence. `This is the first study of its type, and I think it's important as it helps clinicians decide where DPP-4 inhibitors fit in with type 2 diabetes treatment regimens,' he said. He added that he believed the cost of gliptins was an issue: `The cost differential of DPP-4 inhibitors compared with other drugs is stopping them from being more widely used.' BMJ 2012;344:e1369

DOC.TI: Johnson feeling the love again - Once-disgruntled defender signs contract extension with Bombers
DOC.TEXT: Jovan JOHNSON is finally happy. And also a little contrite. The Winnipeg Blue Bombers announced Thursday that contentious off-season talks on a contract extension for the import cornerback -- which included Johnson going public on several occasions, including as recently as last week, with his displeasure -- have concluded with a new deal for the CFL's Outstanding Defensive Player in 2011. Johnson, who was headed into his option year in 2012, said he signed a new one-year deal, plus an option. "I just wanted to be sure where I was going to play at and be sure that, be confident, that the team I was going to play for wanted me," Johnson said in a teleconference Thursday afternoon. "I'd said that over and over and over again and that's where I ultimately wanted to be... "Things worked out for me and the organization and I'm looking forward to 2012." That's a far cry from where Johnson was just last week, when he took to his Twitter account to express his frustration with the progress of negotiations. "This looks like it'll be my last season in BLUE and GOLD! I love all my fans- hope wherever I end up im loved!!," Johnson tweeted, later adding: "Either take pennies and stay or go elsewhere and I'm kinda in disbelief." The tweets were an echo of more extended comments Johnson made to the Free Press in January in which he suggested he felt unappreciated by Bombers management after a historic 2011 season in which he became the first defensive back in CFL history to be named outstanding defensive player. Johnson quickly deleted his tweets last week and subsequently tweeted several apologies to Bombers fans and management, contrition he reiterated with reporters on Thursday. "Players make mistakes and I'm a man and I admit that," said Johnson. "I never had any intention of questioning our management and staff because they do a tremendous job of bringing in players and also signing players that we need. It was just one of those things where emotionally I kind of got upset. "But it happens to the best of us and they look forward to me being a leader on this team and I look forward to going out and doing that. It starts with me and will go down all the way to whoever is the last player on our roster. You can't make mistakes like that and I understand that. "It was definitely the reason I apologized so quickly (after the tweets). I thought about it and it definitely wasn't a good look for me as a player or for what people considered to be a shot at the organization. Because that's not at all the case." Johnson was vague when asked what changed so dramatically in negotiations between last week and this week. "Nothing really changed. Everything that happened is between me and management," said Johnson. "We came to a mutual agreement and everything worked out for the best for both of us." Bombers GM Joe Mack pointed out on Thursday that Johnson plays a larger role for the Bombers than just as a defender. "Clearly, Jovon Johnson is one of the marquee players in this league and we are thrilled to lock him down for the foreseeable future," Mack said in a statement. "His versatility to play special teams in addition to his regular role on defence makes him an even greater asset for us. We are looking for him to take a larger leadership role this season and are confident he is in a position to do so." Johnson led the CFL in 2011 with eight interceptions -- returning two for touchdowns -- and he added 594 punt-return yards to move up to fourth on the Bombers' all-time list. The 2012 season will be his fifth with the Bombers. Johnson becomes the third player this week from last season's East Division champion squad to sign a contract extension. On Wednesday, the club announced non-import receivers Kito Poblah and Cory Watson had signed extensions. paul.wiecek@freepress.mb.ca

DOC.TI: Abbott needs 'personal politics lesson'
DOC.TEXT: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott has again shown he needs a lesson in "personal politics 101" after making inappropriate remarks for a second time in a week, Attorney-General Nicola Roxon says. Mr Abbott said on Friday he regretted a remark he made in reference to Prime Minister Julia Gillard's wardrobe and appearance. Feminist Germaine Greer started the furore after she told an ABC TV panel that Ms Gillard wore unflattering jackets and had a "big arse". A woman speaking to Mr Abbott at a community forum in Victoria on Thursday raised the subject again saying: "Get some of those jackets off her" and he replied: "I know, I know, I know. Germaine Greer was right on that subject." Mr Abbott said he regretted the remark when quizzed on the Nine Network on Friday. "It was an off-the-cuff remark responding to an observation of a member of the public and I shouldn't have said it and I regret it," he said. The latest verbal gaffe came just a week after Mr Abbott apologised in parliament for inappropriately saying Ms Gillard and the leader of the House of Representatives, Anthony Albanese, were "walking around with targets on their foreheads". Ms Roxon reminded reporters on Friday that Mr Abbott had abused Bernie Banton when he was dying from asbestos-induced fibrosis, and had "happily" swore at her (Ms Roxon) after a debate at the National Press Club. "This is Mr Abbott losing control and perhaps being under more pressure than he has been under in a while," she said. "But I also think this is Mr Abbott who needs a lesson on personal politics 101 which is, if your wife or girlfriend says, `Does my bum look big in this?' you say, `No' and get on with it." She didn't think it was appropriate for anyone to comment on the prime minister's clothing, including Ms Greer. "Germaine Greer really didn't do herself proud in making those comments," she said. Workplace Relations Minister Bill Shorten agreed, saying it was a case of an iconic feminist having a crack at another successful woman. "I wouldn't have said what Tony Abbott said, it was just ridiculous," Mr Shorten told the Seven Network. Opposition treasury spokesman Joe Hockey told the same program it was a "no-go area" for any male to talk about female clothing. But he told Fairfax radio that the way one dresses and presents themselves does matter because it forms part of the judgment made of an individual. "For example, I can say to you, with absolute confidence, that you're unlikely to see me in Speedos," he said. But he said both Ms Gillard and Treasurer Wayne Swan had said some "nasty things" about him in the past. "For me it's water off a duck's back. It's no revelation that I'm a fully sized guy," he said. "Frankly when you pass comment about someone's weight or something like that I think it says more about you than it does about them."

DOC.TI: Daily £2 pill to protect against strokes is given go-ahead; The medical watchdog has given its backing to a new £2-a-day pill to help prevent stroke in people with an irregular heart rhythm.
DOC.TEXT: The daily pill is the second drug to be recommended by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (Nice) this month after it approved Pradaxa as an alternative to warfarin to stop blood clots. Rivaroxaban costs just £2.10 a day and unlike the twice-a-day Pradaxa, patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) need only take it once every 24 hours to help thin the blood. It works by suppressing a substance known as Factor Xa, which is an essential component in the process of clotting. People with AF are at a greater risk of blood clots because the condition means irregular heart beats cannot properly pump blood around the body. The risk of a stroke increases fivefold in AF patients. Nice issued draft guidance recommending the pill earlier this week for patients who have diagnosed with non-valvular AF with risk factors including congestive heart failure, hypertension, diabetes or a previous history of strokes. Professor Carole Longson, Nice's health technology evaluation centre director, said: We know that people taking warfarin can find it difficult to maintain their blood clotting at a proper level and are often not within the target therapeutic range. "For example, older people with atrial fibrillation and comorbidities are more likely to have poorly controlled clotting and may be at an increased risk of stroke or bleeding. "Rivaroxaban, like dabigatran etexilate, which Nice recently approved as an option for this indication, can benefit people with AF in these circumstances because it doesn't require such regular monitoring and dose adjustments. Professor Longson added: We are pleased to say that the additional information and analysis received from the manufacturer following our initial draft guidance has enabled us to recommend rivaroxaban as a cost-effective option for the prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in people with atrial fibrillation." Nice has opened a consultation on the draft guidance and until the body issues its final guidance, decisions will be made at regional levels on funding for treatments.

DOC.TI: London election 2012 - Johnson controls.
DOC.TEXT: Over the next three weeks, Property Week will be exploring London's hotly contested mayoral election. Today, Hardeep Sandher meets Boris Johnson. The exclusive St Stephen's Club at Queen Anne's Gate in Westminster is the setting for Property Week's meeting with Boris Johnson. The 19th-century private members club, with its glass chandeliers and private garden, has played host to many a well-known Tory, including Margaret Thatcher and Harold Macmillan - not to mention the overbearing painting of Winston Churchill that hangs in the reception. Yet Boris, as he is known to Londoners, could hardly be more different from these Tory peers. He arrives clutching a handful of crumpled papers and receipts in his right hand, which - unintentionally, I am sure - match his wrinkled suit. He bounds in - early - with a rucksack hanging off his left shoulder, mop of yellow hair flapping, and a buoyant jump in his step. He resembles a teenager, anxiously awaiting his first job interview, rather than a man with one of the country's biggest political mandates. A job interview of sorts is on the cards for Johnson. On 6 May it will be a little more than four years to the day since he secured a surprising win over Ken Livingstone in the battle to become mayor of London. In 2008, tired of Livingstone after eight years, voters were won over by the "BoJo" charm. This year, he is campaigning to entice the capital's voters away from Livingstone once again, as they go head to head for a second time in what is more or less a two-horse race. As far as the property world is concerned, Johnson has remained an anomaly. He has not effected significant change for the industry, yet it has warmed to him considerably - the hubbub caused by his presence at the MIPIM conference in Cannes over the years speaks for itself. The mayor, it seems, has similarly warm feelings towards property. "The property industry contributes massively to London and its beauty," he says. "What they do so well is to integrate an ancient city with the best of modern architecture. It is rewarding to look at the imagination and flair that people are bringing to it." He pauses, before adding: "Is that sufficiently pompous?" It is this wry humour that has attracted both praise and criticism of Johnson over the past four years. He admits that he uses it to "defuse situations". To secure a second term, however, he needs to get serious. London's economy is struggling to recover from the biggest financial crisis for more than 20 years, and the property industry is still largely on its knees when it comes to financing development in the capital. After four years, the mayor's property plan is still unclear. His "war on tall buildings" has subsided since he took office, but affordable housing targets and the community infrastructure levy are still constraining development. The hostility evident during the London riots was enough to put off some of our most important foreign investors. Johnson says he only has one regret about the past four years: "I became mayor just when the markets went off a cliff and my job has been to keep the city going. The worst thing you can do when something bad like that happens is to start cutting investment in infrastructure and things ... so the critical battles I had to win over the past four years were all about securing Crossrail, Tube upgrades and keeping investment in policing. "And we have done that, by the way. Murder in London is down 25%. I mean, beat that, Paris. Beat that, New York. London has got to be a safe city - that is fundamental for property." Building support Property and the built environment seem to be fundamental to Johnson's re-election campaign. His priorities for a second term are leading the city out of recession, making the most of the Olympics and ensuring London has a long-term legacy from the games. On the transport front, he intends to fight for more investment. "All the evidence shows that if we can get the transport stuff right, then that gives property developers the cue to move in," he says. "That's the big picture and from that everything else flows." As an example, he cites "VNEB" - Vauxhall, Nine Elms and Battersea - where two new Northern Line Tube stations have been given the go-ahead. On the back of the stations, City Hall is co-ordinating regeneration of the city's largest undeveloped area. I argue that there is a long way to go, as the stations will have to be funded through a community infrastructure levy on development sites in the area, which the private sector will struggle to afford. Wandsworth Council has set out proposals for this to be up to £575/sq m on residential development. "But we are doing the transport works application right now," booms an excitable Johnson. "The wheels are cranking into life. The great beast is beginning. It has lifted itself off its haunches, and it's moving towards the exit. My job now is to sell that vision to the world." Enticing investors The vision is difficult to sell at a time when money is tight, demand is low and the locations Johnson aims to promote - such as the parcels of land across east London put together by the London Development Agency - are deemed high risk. As an example, I cite the grade II-listed Battersea Power Station, up for sale through administrators from Ernst & Young on behalf of NAMA (Ireland's National Asset Management Agency). "I understand the people who want to take a bulldozer to it," he replies. "I am currently disposed to think that there is still life in some of the plans. And you can be quite creative. Not every brick of (architect Sir) Giles Gilbert Scott's structure has to remain, does it?" And the investors that could create such a vision, could he attract them to London in a second term? "I don't think I have rosy spectacles or anything if I say that London still has immense appeal to international investors. We have the time zone, we have the language and we are signalling to the world that there are unsuspected bargains here. "You'll just think I am a salesman, but when I go to Davos and MIPIM, I don't just knock back the wine and come back empty-handed." Johnson says he met an investor from Bahrain in Davos, Switzerland, last month who told him he wanted to spend £10bn in London. "That's the kind of enthusiasm out there," he says. "I want to see deals done. I want to form those relationships with people." His vision for promoting London is exactly what the property industry craves. But it has not been easy since images of Croydon and Tottenham on fire were beamed around the world during August 2011's riots. That episode will forever be remembered as part of his mayoral term, particularly as he was on holiday at the time. He admits it was a terrible knock for London. "But we are working hard to repair things. (Sir) Stuart (Lipton) is doing some great work for us in Tottenham, where we secured £20m of funding to go into the area from DCLG (department for Communities and Local Government). The Olympics gives us an opportunity to correct things this year." It was Livingstone who worked alongside Lord Coe in 2004 to bring the games to London. But it is Johnson who is reaping the rewards and who plans to "leverage the games" to London's benefit this summer. "During games time, City Hall will be a kind of trade fair," says Johnson, speaking with the confidence that has helped to widen his lead over Livingstone in the latest poll this month. "I will shamelessly use City Hall to bring people together. As you know, we have a small number of tickets that we will give to people we think will bring the hundreds of millions of pounds to London." It is not surprising that Derwent London chief executive John Burns refers to the mayor as an "ambassadorial force" in helping London to compete for investment when it was at its weakest. And in some ways it has worked: several new initiatives for property have been announced since 2008. The enterprise zone status of east London's Royal Docks has encouraged developers to consider regeneration strategies. Johnson also lobbied to take control of the Homes and Communities Agency's London money and assets, which central government allocated to him after the break-up of the agency in 2010. Johnson says his planning policies were simplified in 2010 through a review of the London Plan. And next week, the Mayoral Development Corporation (MDC) will be launched to help to streamline planning applications on the Olympic Park legacy site, in the hope of attracting investors. If he is re-elected, the planning processes could be further simplified, as the corporation's powers could be extended across London sites. "The MDC is innovative," says Johnson. "(If it were to be extended to other sites,) it would mean boroughs' prerogatives would be taken away, and we don't want to do that, unless they really want us to. But if the boroughs do want such powers ... we would be keen to help." The industry has accused him of confusing them with such initiatives and making the planning system unpredictable - he has used controversial powers, brought in by Livingstone, to overrule planning decisions several times in the past year. Incoming Land Securities chief Robert Noel says that, although the industry thinks Johnson has done well, he needs to provide a steer on whether or not he is going to be pragmatic about affordable housing targets and tax, both of which make some developments unviable. Johnson says he does not have "a one size fits all doctrine" towards development. "As mayor, you have to keep working, working, working, to compete on things where we need to improve. Housing, transport, regeneration. That is why I want to be mayor, to fight for it and make London the best place to live in the world," he says. "This city will grow by a million people in a decade and the need for housing will have to be dealt with sensitively. If people say they can't predict what I am going to say then that is a good thing. We look at the context and the local need." In a lighter tone, he adds: "I do enjoy these conversations with developers. I mean, these people are no slouches. They are clever people and they are not against things like affordable housing. They know what is good for London." Game on Does he know what is good for London better than his rival, who has promised a 7% cut in transport fares in a bid to win votes? Johnson pauses for thought before he responds: "The safest thing for an incumbent in any election is to focus on the future. The less said about competitors the better." He cannot help but take a swipe at Ken: "I will say, however, that to cut £1bn from Transport for London's budget is ludicrous. He doesn't really mean it. I don't think even if he did get into office - which he, I hope, won't - I don't believe he will deliver it." And with that, he is off, pulling on his beanie hat, teenage rucksack in tow - on his Boris bike.

DOC.TI: Two nations divided by a common coffee; Our addiction to Starbucks, Costa and the like has never been stronger.
DOC.TEXT: A few weeks ago in a New York Starbucks I had the chance to put to the test George Bernard Shaws maxim that America and Britain are two nations divided by a common language". Jet-lagged, cold and thirsty after a misguided hour trying to walk to the Brooklyn Bridge, I fancied a cup of coffee. The barista, however, was determined to subject me to a rigorous inquisition first. While I was already familiar with the ridiculous lingo of their cup sizes (venti, which means big; grande, which means medium; and tall, which means nothing at all), the rest of our conversation might as well have been conducted in Esperanto. Did I want half and half"? Did I want empty space with that"? And, of course, the one that has recently become policy in Britain but has long been routine in the States: Whats your name?" By this point I was so flustered by trying to work out what to do with my empty space (it is so that you can add your own milk, apparently) that, instead of giving my name, I said, in fluent American, To go, please." My wife tried to hide her giggles as the barista dutifully wrote down Togo" on my venti, half-half, empty-space caffeine product. If there was any justice in the world, coffee chains would have long gone the way of the dodo. No more uncomfortable chairs, meaningless marketing slogans, piped music, annoying wall poetry, overpriced muffins, eager tip bowls, unsubtle upselling, unreliable Wi-Fi connections, dirty tables, locked lavatories and the pervasive whiff of rancid milk. And yet they continue to go from strength to strength. A survey published yesterday found that Britons spend at least £15,600 in coffee shops over a lifetime. Last year British coffee shop sales grew by 10 per cent to reach £2.1 billion, twice the level of 2005. The rest of our economy may not be going great guns, but at least we can maintain a constant state of nervous energy while it flounders around our ears. Its not going to stop here, either. In February, Starbucks announced a Renaissance" plan given that it already has 20,000 stores worldwide, I wasnt aware that it needed rebirth. It proposed to focus on adding hundreds more outlets in Europe, notably in airports, service stations and hotels. The Onion, an American satirical magazine, had the measure of it when it wrote the spoof headline back in June 1998: New Starbucks opens in rest room of existing Starbucks". So why do we do it? Why do we maintain this love/hate but mainly hate relationship with Starbucks and its slightly less awful siblings, Caffè Nero and Costa? There are a few obvious theories: were constantly tired; were addicted to the caffeine; were addicted to the routine. A commute is more bearable if you have a polystyrene comfort blanket. A latte break in the office wont kill you as quickly as a fag break; indeed, if research is to be believed, moderate coffee consumption reduces the risk of heart disease, cancer, type 2 diabetes and Alzheimers. If youre out and about, coffee chains offer warmth, familiarity, a cheap meeting room and the chance to go to the loo. They are marginally preferable to sitting on the pavement or buying your own machine, which costs the same as a small car. One wonders, though, how much longer this will be the case. Earlier this month Starbucks unveiled a teeth-pulling advertisement in which they seem to be labouring under the delusion that they are a person, not a shop that sells coffee. Were Starbucks, nice to meet you," says a chirpy northerner Ive never met. Have you noticed how everything seems a little impersonal nowadays?" Whereas weve all become user names, reference numbers and IP addresses", he promises to refer to us as your folks intended: by your name". And so, where America leads, Britain follows with predictably annoying results. I tried it out in London yesterday. The result? Togo" has become Ean". No doubt such an approach is intended to improve efficiency and harness brand loyalty. Yet it also achieves the unique feat of making the customer feel that the barista is being both too personal and too impersonal. Next time that Im asked how I would like my coffee to be served, I am going to request a venti dollop of anonymity.

DOC.TI: Bausch + Lomb to acquire Ista Pharmaceuticals.
DOC.TEXT: Bausch + Lomb and Ista Pharmaceuticals Inc (Ista) have signed a definitive agreement under which Bausch + Lomb will acquire Ista for $9.10/share in cash, or a total of about $500 M. The transaction, which has been unanimously approved by the boards of directors of both companies, is expected to close in 2Q 2012. Bausch + Lomb's acquisition of Ista accelerates the company's strategy to strengthen its pipeline and marketed products and capabilities. The transaction is expected to drive growth and high performance for the long term. The combination adds Ista's portfolio of industry-proven non-steroidal, anti-inflammatory, allergy, glaucoma and spreading agents to Bausch + Lomb's robust, complementary portfolio of existing Rx ophthalmology and OTC eye health products. The companies also have complementary development pipelines. The transaction, which is expected to be accretive to Bausch + Lomb's EBITDA in the first year after close, is subject to regulatory approval and other customary closing conditions, including the approval of Ista's shareholders. The companies will continue to operate independently until completion of the transaction. Bausch + Lomb currently intends to finance the acquisition with a combination of cash on hand and the proceeds of a $350 M incremental term loan facility to be provided under its existing credit facility and available borrowings under its existing revolving credit facilities or, alternatively, to obtain other financing in lieu of the foregoing (provided that Bausch + Lomb intends in all cases to have a combination of cash on hand and committed financing sufficient to finance the acquisition). Bausch + Lomb has obtained commitments for the full amount of the incremental facility from Citigroup Global Markets Inc, JPMorgan Chase Bank NA, Credit Suisse AG, Goldman Sachs Bank USA, and Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch. This purchase price reflects a 10% premium to the share price as of the market close on 23 Mar 2012, a 40% premium to the proposal letter Ista publicly confirmed it received from Valeant Pharmaceuticals and a 134% premium to the share price on 15 Dec 2011, the trading day prior to Ista's announcement of the proposal letter it received from Valeant Pharmaceuticals and the Ista board's announcement of its intention to review strategic options. Goldman, Sachs & Co served as financial advisor to Bausch + Lomb in this transaction and Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton LLP served as legal counsel. Greenhill & Co served as financial advisor to Ista and Stradling Yocca Carlson & Rauth and WilmerHale LLP served as legal advisors. Ista Pharmaceuticals Inc is a fast growing and the third largest branded prescription eye care business in the US with an expanding focus on allergy therapeutics. Bausch + Lomb is one of the best-known and most respected healthcare companies in the world. Marketwire Website:

DOC.TI: Diabetes study could create new class of surgical candidates
DOC.TEXT: A study published by the New England Journal of Medicine could create waves in the type 2 diabetes community. The study, which followed 150 patients with uncontrollable type 2 diabetes, showed gastric bypass may be the best intervention, trumping medication and sleeve-gastronectomy, which is a variation of gastric bypass. The results showed the gastric bypass kicked type 2 diabetes into remission and was of particular note because the changeover happened before patients hit their weight goals. Most of the surgery patients also reined in their glucose levels without medication. Of added value was that the patient class hovered in the 30-35 BMI range, which is a unique class, because it focuses on a group that is not necessarily the heaviest of heavy-set sufferers. President of the American Society for Metabolic & Bariatric Surgery Robin Blackstone told MM&M that the results may prompt doctors to discuss surgery with patients sooner. She also said it was important to note that the glucose control occurred before weight loss. Gastric banding, which restricts the stomach as opposed to rewiring the gastrointestinal track, can ameliorate diabetes, but only after weight loss. Blackstone noted that the findings show that the surgery isn't really about obesity anymore. She said that the results essentially create a new type of gastric bypass surgery by converting patients in a BMI range that was previously excluded from surgical consideration into viable surgical candidates. They're not surgical candidates for the treatment of obesity, but they are for the treatment of diabetes. She said she expects it may take a few years before insurers are persuaded that these patients are indeed surgical candidates, but that doctors may begin discussing the surgery as a treatment option for this discrete set of patients within the year. The significance for the overall diabetes community could be substantialthe Centers for Disease Control reports that 90% to 95% of all adult diabetes cases are type 2 diabetes. Predictions are that associated triggers, including a soaring obesity rate, are going to push the number of type 2 diabetes cases even higher, adding even greater pressure on the direct medical costs$116 billionthe CDC associates with the disease. This is in addition to the $58 billion in indirect costs, such as lost productivity, the agency links to both forms of diabetes.

DOC.TI: Novo Nordisk/SHB: Victoza kan i værste fald blive forsinket
DOC.TEXT: Novo Nordisks kommercielle lancering af Victoza i fedmebehandling kan blive forsinket i et par år til 2016 fra 2014. Det vurderer Handelsbanken Capital Markets, efter et ekspertpanel under den amerikanske lægemiddelstyrelse, FDA, torsdag anbefalede at skærpe kravene til kommende vægttabsmidler. - Hvis FDA vælger at følge det uafhængige panels anbefaling, kan det betyde, at Novo Nordisk kan blive nødt til at gennemføre et yderligere studie, som påviser at Victoza til behandling af fedme ikke påfører patienter betydelige hjerte-kar problemer. Det kan i værste fald betyde at Victoza til behandling af fedme først bliver kommercielt lanceret to år senere end planlagt. Det er dog endnu for tildigt at sige, at dette bliver udfaldet, konstaterer banken i sin morgenkommentar. Også Jyske Bank og Nordea vurderer, at Victozas lancering som fedmebehandlingsmiddel kan forsinkes i to til tre år. Handelsbanken fastholder anbefalingen "akkumuler" med et kursmål på 909 kr. Banken har ikke indregnet værdi af Victoza til behandling af fedme i sine nuværende modeller. - Vi venter dog, at Novo-aktien kan komme under pres på helt kort sigt indtil der er mere klarhed om hvorvidt FDA vil kræve yderligere studier for Victoza til behandling af fedme. Men fundamentalt set er der efter vores vurdering intet ændret i Novo-casen og vurderer at et tilbagefald vil være en god opkøbsmulighed, skriver Handelsbanken. FDA-eksperterne anbefalede torsdag aften med stemmerne 17-6 at gennemføre hjerte-kar-studier, selv hvis der ikke er synlige tegn på, at stoffet øger risikoen for hjerte-kar-sygdomme. Panelet anbefalede samtidig at inkludere endnu flere patienter i risikogruppen i studierne, det vil sige patienter, der lider af svær fedme og ældre og endnu sygere patienter. FDA følger normalt indstillingerne fra ekspertpanelerne, men har det endelige ord i forhold til at udvikle de nye retningslinjer for fedmemedicin. DOC.TI: Expect Crude to trade with a sideways bias today: Angel
DOC.TEXT: Angel Commodities has come out with its report on metals and energy. According to the research firm, crude oil prices are expected to trade with a sideways bias today taking cues from expectations of strategic crude oil reserves release from the Western Nations. Nymex crude oil prices declined by 2.5 percent yesterday the biggest decline in this year taking cues from French Prime Minister Mr. Francois Fillon statement that prospectus are looking good for US-Europe agreement for a release of strategic crude oil reserves coupled with International Energy Agency said that they are ready to release the reserves if supply is disrupted. Additionally, US President Mr. Barack Obama called a meeting to end subsidies worth $ 4 billion for oil and natural gas companies and divert that money towards clean energy fuels. Oil prices touched an intra-day low of $ /bbl and closed at $ /bbl in yesterday's trading session. On the MCX, prices declined around 2 percent and closed at Rs.5293/bbl after touching an intra-day low of Rs.5271/bbl on Thursday. News: US representatives Ted Deutch, a Florida Democrat and Robert Dold, an Illinois Republican, introduced the Iran Energy Sector and Proliferation Sanctions Act in Congress meeting yesterday. This latest measure is taken to speed up the campaign of tightening sanctions on Iran. In response to sanctions, Iran the second biggest producer in Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has raised supply concern by threatening to shut the Strait of Hormuz which supplies fifth of world's crude oil. Natural Gas: Nymex natural gas prices declined around 4.3 percent yesterday on the back of more than expected rise in US natural gas inventories. Gas prices touched an intra-day low of $ 2.132/mmbtu and closed at $ 2.17/mmbtu in yesterday's trading session. EIA Inventories: US Energy Information Administration (EIA) released its weekly inventories yesterday and US natural gas inventory has increased more than expected by 57 billion cubic feet (bcf) to 2.437 trillion cubic feet for the week ending on 23rd March 2012. Outlook: We expect crude oil prices to trade with a sideways bias today taking cues from expectations of strategic crude oil reserves release from the Western Nations. However, supply worries from Iran may provide some support to oil prices. Natural gas prices are also expected to trade with a negative bias today. DOC.TI: Man, 76, survives 10 days in the desert using 'Boy Scout' skills; A 76-year-old diabetic man survived 10 days in the remote Nevada desert by melting snow and using skills he learned as a Boy Scout, but a friend who was with him and ventured away to get help died.
DOC.TEXT: James Klemovich and Laszlo Szabo, 75, went to scope out some mines in the state when their car became stuck on a lonely road with no cell phone service, Klemovich's wife, Joanne, said on Thursday. The men tried unsuccessfully to dislodge the car, and lit flares and started fires in hopes somebody would see them in northwestern Nevada's Pershing County, an area where less than 7,000 people are spread over 6,000 square miles. They used a towel in the car to strain ditch water and snow into water bottles, but, after four or five days, Szabo left to get help. Joanne Klemovich began to worry when several days passed without a phone call from her husband. "I figured maybe they'd had an accident and they were stranded," she said. "I thought maybe they were in a mine shaft. All kinds of things were going through my head." Joanne Klemovich said she was expecting the worst when authorities called on Tuesday night to say her husband had been found by military personnel who were holding training exercises in the area. "I thought it was bad news, but it was very good news," she said by telephone from the couple's home in Littleton, Colorado, . "I didn't know what to even do or say." James Klemovich has diabetes, wears a pacemaker and had a triple bypass heart surgery, his wife said. He told her he wasn't panicking while he sat for days waiting for Szabo's return, she said. He kept a journal, noting how much water he drank and what he did each day. And he wrote a letter each day for her. Drinking regularly was likely the biggest factor in his survival despite the diabetes that could have sent his blood sugar dangerously out of whack, according to Rita Kalyani, who teaches endocrinology at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore. During a fast, she said, the body can draw glucose from the liver or from fat stores to keep levels from dropping too low. But having enough water is essential to flush out excess glucose and prevent levels from rising too high. When the military personnel found Klemovich, they gave him a banana, two oranges and three boiled eggs, he told his wife. Szabo, of Lovelock, Nevada, was found dead about a mile and a half away . An autopsy is being performed. Klemovich said her husband hasn't been talking much about his friend and that she doesn't know whether Szabo has any close relatives. "When I first talked to him I could tell he'd been through an ordeal," she said. "When he called back, he sounded pretty good." James Klemovich is still in Nevada, waiting for the car to be recovered before returning home. He was treated and released from a hospital. Source: agencies

DOC.TI: Local veteran wants benefits \ VETERANS AFFAIRS
DOC.TEXT: WOODSTOCK-He fought for the Allies in the Korean War and worries he'll spend the rest of what he has left of his life fighting for benefits he thinks he deserves. On the same day he was released from hospital after suffering his second heart attack, Woodstock resident John Wood expressed outrage over his ineligibility to receive help from Veterans Affairs Canada. When released, his doctor didn't waste time mixing words. "My doc says this is the last one I'll have because the damage is too severe. If I have another one, I'm dead," he said. Wood is a longtime sufferer of diabetes, so much so that kidney disease has developed and he's lost most of his eyesight. He also experiences severe arthritis in his knees and joints, and is currently on oxygen. Over the past few years, as his health has deteriorated, the 77-year-old has called Veterans Affairs several times pleading for help. But each time, he has been told the same thing. No help is coming because he and his wife Margaret, 73, earn too much money. "I don't really have that much money. What I'm afraid of is we'll spend everything trying to keep me going, and when I go, they'll be hardly anything left for her," he said. Between his pension from Alexandra hospital, her pension from her work as a bookkeeper and their government pensions, the couple makes more than the $2,000 a month, making them ineligible for Allied Veterans benefi ts. "I don't make over the amount, but with my wife's pension, we do. But I want to know why they are taking away money from my wife. I was the one that fought in Korea -not my wife," he said. "I just want some help, that's what I fought for. What the hell are we fighting for if we can't get help when we're older." Wood, who was born in Halifax, England, served the last two years of the Korean War in high combat zones. He was hospitalized when his eardrums were punctured and still suffers from hearing loss. He moved to Canada shortly after the war in 1956. Margaret moved over from England a year later and the couple was married. "I've done everything all these years. I've worked, paid all my taxes and I've saved a little bit of money. It just feels like I'm being penalized. I don't want money. I want someone to help us around the house, do some light cleaning, cut the grass and shovel the driveway. My wife has a terrible back and I just can't do much anymore," he said. Wood said there have been agencies that have stepped up to help. An employee from Community Care Access Centre comes in each morning to help Wood get washed and dressed for the day. A member of the Red Cross comes and sits with him for two hours once a week so his wife can go have a coffee and relax. And his 53-year-old son and his wife help around the house as much as they can. "I just don't want to be a burden for all of them. I think Veterans Affairs can help me. They should help me. I helped when I was needed and now I need help," he said. Although Simon Forsyth, a media relations officer for Veterans Affairs, could not comment on Wood and his troubles, he did issue some background on the offering of Allied benefits. It wasn't until January 2010 that the federal government began offering some benefits to low-income Allied veterans who served in the Korean War. At the same time, the government restored benefits, after a 15-year hiatus, to Second World War Allied veterans residing in Canada, including the War Veterans Allowance, the Funeral and Burial Assistance Program, the Veterans Independence Program and long-term care. Benefits are not eligible to those who file income taxes as a single and make more than $1,381.56 or $2,095.33 if they are married. "A top priority at Veterans Affairs Canada is making sure that veterans and their families have the support they need, when they need it," he said in an e-mail. tbowie@bowesnet.com

DOC.TI: Mother knows best at Hatton; Donation pays for Southington school's new play equipment
DOC.TEXT: SOUTHINGTON - Hatton School has a new addition to its playground. Thanks to a donation from the parent of a student, new parallel bars, a climbing pole, an incline slide and over-under bars will be used by the kindergarten-through-fifth-grade students there. More than $7,000 worth of equipment has been installed next to the playscape. Wednesday, fifth-graders and their physical education teacher, Marcia Phelps, tried out the new equipment, with Phelps offering tips on appropriate use. "Kids don't climb trees anymore," Phelps said. "This equipment is designed to improve upper body strength." Children ran back and forth among the pieces of equipment. After Phelps would demonstrate an exercise, students would imitate her. They attempted to pull themselves up the climbing poles. On the parallel bars, students lifted themselves and spun around. Many swung from bars and tried to do chin-ups. "One of the biggest issues today is childhood obesity," Phelps said. "As a way to combat that, this equipment was purchased." Marissa Salsbury, mother of fifthgrader Ethan Salsbury, was the donor. After the equipment was bought and installed and the ground mulched, she donated $10,000. "My father always gave back and I wanted to do the same thing," Salsbury said. Salsbury is a member of the school's Parent-Teacher Organization, and said that, while she and others always work hard to raise funds and get people to help, little money comes in. "It's difficult to do anything," she said. "I decided to do it myself." With society focusing on fitness, Salsbury thought it would be a great idea to buy equipment that provides children with safe, athletic fun. "The equipment is going to be there for years to come," she said. "Kids can play on it during school and after school on the weekends." Salsbury also kept physically handicapped children in mind when deciding what equipment to buy. Those children can use the equipment to build strength, she said. Salsbuy said she and Hatton Principal Roberta McAloon had discussed installing a rock climbing wall, but decided that students would get more use from outdoor equipment. McAloon said Salsbury's decision to make a donation was a wonderful surprise. "We took the time and went through the catalogs to figure out what was the most fitting for the school," she said. "It's a great addition. It fits in nicely with our physical fitness curriculum." Phelps said the equipment is much different from typical playground structures. "These are like fitness stations," Phelps said. Once students become familiar with the equipment, Phelps said she'll develop challenges for them. Ethan Salsbury was among the students using the equipment Wednesday afternoon. "I think it's good," Ethan said. "We'll have more fun at recess." Ethan said his favorite new piece of equipment is the climbing pole. "It's fun, you can climb up and slide back down easily," he said. kprimicerio@record-journal.com (203) 317-2279

DOC.TI: Can diet changes ease chronic inflammation?
DOC.TEXT: Q. Can my diet contribute to chronic inflammation? A. The foods you are eating may be the root of some major health problems and even contribute to your achy joints. How many of these foods end up on your plate each day? Saturated fats, which are found in animal products like meats and dairy. Trans-fats, which can be found in processed foods, baked goods and some oils. Sugar: Yes, table sugar is important to avoid, but added sugar is the real culprit. Refined carbohydrates, which are made with processed, white flour and contain little to no fiber. Here are some healthy upgrades: Choose low-fat dairy products and lean meats. Minimize processed foods. Eat fruits, vegetables and whole grains. Hungry? Here are some foods that may help reduce chronic inflammation: Foods that are rich in omega-3 are key. Try salmon, ahi tuna, sardines, nuts and seeds like flax, chia and hemp. Olive oil, onion, turmeric, garlic and ginger have chemicals that act as a pain reliever and anti-inflammatory. Berries, as well as deep red and purple fruits, are loaded with antioxidants and free radical-fighting properties that can aid in the prevention of chronic inflammation. Broccoli, asparagus, carrots and many other deep orange and dark green vegetables are loaded with phyto-nutrients to prevent inflammation. All types of tea have anti-inflammatory properties. Courtesy Katie Cavuto Boyle on foodnetwork.com Scripps Howard News Service

DOC.TI: Affymax Inc, MAP Pharmaceuticals Inc drug approvals would net royalty bounty for Nektar Therapeutics.
DOC.TEXT: San Francisco-based Nektar Therapeutics (Nektar) is in line for royalty payments if the Food and Drug Administration approves an acute migraine drug from MAP Pharmaceuticals Inc (MAP) and partner Allergan Inc. It would collect more royalties if an anaemia drug from Affymax Inc and Takeda Pharmaceutical Co Ltd is approved. Both drugs use know-how developed by and licensed from Nektar. Signed within months of each other in 2002, the licensing deals are typical of the pacts made between drug developers: company A with a technology meets company B with a drug, they decide there's a match and they consummate the relationship, legally speaking. Often in these long-term affairs, however, one or both partners die along the way and the booty is captured by one of their descendants. But the MAP and Affymax deals with Nektar have the potential to write rare happy endings, with three Bay Area companies and with the drug approvals coming a day apart. Analysts peg peak sales of Levadex from Mountain View-based MAP at $400 M to $500 M. Peginesatide from Palo Alto-based Affymax could garner revenue in the neighbourhood of $350 M to $550 M. In the end, that could translate into a good deal of coin for Nektar. Its royalties for Levadex and peginesatide are believed to be in the mid-single digits. Nektar in Feb 2012 sold the potential royalty revenue from Mircera and Cimzia to a unit of Royalty Pharma for $124 M. Nektar said it would use the Royalty Pharma bounty to pay down a convertible note that is due in Sep 2012 - and it said it was mulling the sale of other royalty interests as well. BioSpace Website:

DOC.TI: CLOSE TO HOME: STICKING WITH PLAZA PLAN IS SMART
DOC.TEXT: Changes are happening rapidly now that redevelopment agencies statewide in California have been dissolved. Sonoma County's oversight board this week supported the continuation of the Roseland Plaza project on Sebastopol Road in Santa Rosa. The board's decision will be reviewed by the state Department of Finance, which will have the final say on which projects continue and which properties are liquidated. In terms of the Roseland Plaza, the oversight board determined that it is more valuable to collect taxes on the businesses around a newly created plaza in the future than to sell off the property now. The plaza is the heart of a vision plan for the Sebastopol Road corridor and the Roseland Village Shopping Center in particular. There are a lot of people who care deeply about the plaza, beginning with Roseland residents who long for a public square to make it easy to socialize, shop and celebrate as a community. Think of the impact that having a Town Green has made to Windsor. To realize this vision, finding new partners to offset the loss of Redevelopment funds is critical. Interestingly, there are other entities that have a stake in seeing Roseland develop in a walkable fashion. One is Plan Bay Area and the Metropolitan Transportation Commission. Sebastopol Road has been designated as a "priority development area" to reduce greenhouse gases. These represent neighborhoods where there is local commitment to develop housing along with amenities and services to meet day-to-day needs of residents in a walkable environment served by transit.MTC can help fund transportation related projects in Roseland. Another stakeholder is Sonoma County's health department. Using a variety of health-related grant funding, more than $1 million has been spent by the health department on the Roseland and Kawana Springs areas to stem the tide of obesity and its related chronic diseases. A survey done in 2007 reported that 65 percent of the population in south Santa Rosa is overweight or obese. The rise in obesity in the United States correlates with decades of development patterns that have made walking and bicycling difficult or impossible. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimated that the direct medical costs of physical inactivity totaled more than $76 billion in 2000. If departments such as health, human services and planning and the city of Santa Rosa were to seek innovative ways to apply for community health-related grants or identify creative financing strategies, they could build on all the work that has been accomplished to date. These planning efforts could extend the walkable benefits of the plaza to a larger area. A specific plan would rezone the area within a quarter-mile of the new plaza as well as the other neighborhoods along the Sebastopol Road corridor. This type of zoning adds street connections and compels interesting building fronts behind sidewalks. This makes it safe and enjoyable for residents to walk to transit stops. Given that the benefits of continuing with the Roseland Plaza project are economic, social, environmental and health-related for the Roseland Community, it is wonderful that the oversight board has recommended that the Roseland Plaza project be continued. Providing that the state Department of Finance retains this project, the next step would be for the oversight board and county supervisors to direct that a newly focused collaborative effort between health, planning, social services and MTC be undertaken to apply for planning or development grants. Lois Fisher is an urban designer with Fisher Town Design. She lives in Windsor.

DOC.TI: Australia's Tony Abbott 'regrets' derogatory remarks about Julia Gillard; Australian opposition leader Tony Abbott back-pedalled on Friday after derogatory comments about the clothes and appearance of Julia Gillard, the country's first female prime minister.
DOC.TEXT: The furore began when well-known Australian feminist Germaine Greer told ABC television that Gillard wore unflattering jackets and had a "big a-se". "Every time she turns round, you've got that strange horizontal crease, which means they're cut too narrow in the hips," Greer said. "You've got a big a-se, Julia. Just get on with it." While meeting the public at a community forum on Thursday the issue came up and Mr Abbott responded: "I know, I know, I know. Germaine Greer was right on that subject." On Friday he said he regretted the remark after it was widely played on television. "It was an off-the-cuff remark responding to an observation of a member of the public and I shouldn't have said it and I regret it," he said. Miss Gillard is Australia's first female leader and her boyfriend Tim Mathieson has previously hit out at people "bullying" her. "Being a woman, I think she's gets targeted quite a bit by the big boys in town," he said at the time. "Bullying women just doesn't work for me ... calling females names does not get you anywhere," he added. Source: agencies

DOC.TI: MOgene LC, a NimbleGen service provider, signs agreement with Lawrence Livermore National Lab to offer microbial detection array services.
DOC.TEXT: MOgene LC has announced the signing of an agreement with Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) to provide services using the Lawrence Livermore Microbial Detection Array (LLMDA). The technology of the LLMDA, which includes probes for more than 3000 bacterial and viral species, has been optimised for NimbleGen arrays. The Livermore-developed array provides rapid and comprehensive analysis of bacteria or viruses from biological material of unknown nature. This capability has been shown to be very useful in food and pharmaceutical safety, detection of viral and bacterial infections, and animal health, as well as many other applications. MOgene signed an agreement with LLNL for the potential it offers to its existing customers and because it allows the company to expand into new areas for our microarray and sequencing service business. The LLMDA could enable food safety professionals, law enforcement, medical professionals and others to detect within 24 hours any virus or bacteria that has been sequenced and included among the array's probes. It detects viruses and bacteria with the use of 388,000 probes that fit in a checkerboard pattern in the middle of a one-inch wide, three-inch long glass slide. One advantage of the LLMDA is that it provides researchers with the capability of detecting pathogens over the entire range of known viruses and bacteria. Current multiplex polymerase chain reaction techniques can at most offer detection from among 50 organisms in one test. MOgene has been in the genomics service business since 2004 and has worked with many pharmaceutical and agricultural businesses, along with universities, around the world. MOgene LC is a leading global genomics service provider located in St Louis, MO. MOgene. Marketwire Website:
