DOC.TI: 'Abbott needs personal politics lesson'
DOC.TEXT: OPPOSITION Leader Tony Abbott has again shown he needs a lesson in "personal politics 101" after making inappropriate remarks for a second time in a week, Attorney-General Nicola Roxon says. Mr Abbott said he regretted a remark he made in reference to Prime Minister Julia Gillard's wardrobe and appearance. Feminist Germaine Greer started the furore after she told an ABC TV panel that Ms Gillard wore unflattering jackets and had a "big arse". A woman speaking to Mr Abbott at a community forum in Victoria yesterday raised the subject again saying: "Get some of those jackets off her" and he replied: "I know, I know, I know. Germaine Greer was right on that subject." Mr Abbott said he regretted the remark when quizzed on the Channel 9 today. "It was an off-the-cuff remark responding to an observation of a member of the public and I shouldn't have said it and I regret it," he said. The latest verbal gaffe came just a week after Mr Abbott apologised in parliament for inappropriately saying Ms Gillard and the leader of the House of Representatives, Anthony Albanese, were "walking around with targets on their foreheads". Ms Roxon reminded reporters on Friday that Mr Abbott had abused Bernie Banton when he was dying from asbestos-induced fibrosis, and had "happily" swore at her (Ms Roxon) after a debate at the National Press Club. "This is Mr Abbott losing control and perhaps being under more pressure than he has been under in a while," she said. "But I also think this is Mr Abbott who needs a lesson on personal politics 101 which is, if your wife or girlfriend says, 'Does my bum look big in this?' you say, 'No' and get on with it." She didn't think it was appropriate for anyone to comment on the prime minister's clothing, including Ms Greer. "Germaine Greer really didn't do herself proud in making those comments," she said. Workplace Relations Minister Bill Shorten agreed, saying it was a case of an iconic feminist having a crack at another successful woman. "I wouldn't have said what Tony Abbott said, it was just ridiculous," Mr Shorten told Channel 7. Opposition treasury spokesman Joe Hockey told the same program it was a "no-go area" for any male to talk about female clothing. But he told Fairfax radio that the way one dresses and presents themselves does matter because it forms part of the judgment made of an individual. "For example, I can say to you, with absolute confidence, that you're unlikely to see me in Speedos," he said. But he said both Ms Gillard and Treasurer Wayne Swan had said some "nasty things" about him in the past. "For me it's water off a duck's back. It's no revelation that I'm a fully sized guy," he said. "Frankly when you pass comment about someone's weight or something like that I think it says more about you than it does about them."

DOC.TI: Davies and Partners Solicitors Medical Negligence Specialists; ADVERTISEMENT
DOC.TEXT: " In general the hospital care we receive in the UK is excellent and most surgery is completely successful. However, there are occasions when things do go wrong and this is when you would require the help of specialist lawyers to help you pursue a medical negligence claim. Davies and Partners Solicitors has one of the largest Medical Negligence teams in the UK. All our solicitors are experts in their field including five members of the Law Society Accreditation Scheme and three members of the AvMA specialists panel. We offer comprehensive advice and expertise in all areas of medical negligence and have received notable acclaim for our achievements in the highly complex area of catastrophic injury arising from birth or other trauma. The firm holds a clinical negligence franchise enabling us to offer Legal Aid work. We provide a quality service for many successful claimants every year and we have recovered millions of pounds of compensation on behalf of clients. If you need any advice and a no obligation discussion about your particular case, then please contact our Ewan Lockhart Partner & Head of Clinical Negligence & Personal Injury team." Our areas of expertise Davies and Partners Solicitors has one of the largest Medical Negligence teams in the South West focusing on all areas of medical and clinical practice including: ¦ Medical, dental or plastic surgery ¦ Neurology ¦ Orthopaedics ¦ Obstetrics ¦ Gynaecology ¦ Catastrophic injury ¦ Inquests CASE STUDY Death from pressure sores Davies and Partners settled a clinical negligence claim for a client whose wife died as a result of severe pressure sores which developed while she was an in patient at St Michael's hospital in Bristol. The 64 year old lady was a newly-diagnosed diabetic who failed to recover as expected from a hysterectomy. At a 4 day inquest hospital staff admitted failing to follow national and Trust guidelines on nursing care aimed at preventing and managing pressure sores. The Deputy Coroner for Avon, nonetheless, returned a verdict setting out the circumstances of her death and stating that this occurred despite a satisfactory level of care. Following the inquest Davies and Partners sent a lengthy pre-action letter of claim to University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust, coupled with a settlement offer. Lawyers at the NHS Litigation Authority took a different view from the Deputy Coroner and agreed to pay damages and costs, including the costs of representation at the inquest. CASE STUDY Failure to diagnose and treat fatal DVT Davies and Partners acted for a widower Mr A, whose wife died following a GPs failure to examine and identify a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which resulted in his wife having a fatal pulmonary embolism. Mrs A had flown back to the UK following a period overseas. On her return she became concerned about a swelling in her left ankle. Over the next few weeks she attended the GP surgery on three separate occasions as the swelling in her ankle continued and had spread to her leg. During these three visits she saw two different GPs. The first recorded that clinically there was no sign of DVT, but referred Mrs A for an urgent abdominal ultrasound scan. The second GP, recorded that there was left ankle swelling and slight pain but concluded that there was no DVT and prescribed Frusemide. Two days later Mrs A collapsed and was taken to hospital. Resuscitation was unsuccessful and she died due to a pulmonary embolism arising from the DVT in the left leg. Mrs A's husband brought a case against the first GP based on his negligence in failing to obtain a full history from his wife on her first visit including failing to ask about recent foreign travel; he had also failed to undertake an adequate examination and to consider Mrs A's continued condition on subsequent visits. If Mrs A had been admitted to hospital for the relevant scans and appropriate treatment following any of her visits to the surgery or she had been provided with anti-coagulant drugs, the fatal pulmonary embolism would have been avoided. After a period of negotiation a settlement was agreed and approved by the Court in the global sum of £77,500. CASE STUDY Case against North Bristol NHS Trust Davies and Partners acted for M in respect of a claim arising out of her husband's death. In 2007, the deceased developed chest pain whilst in Southmead Hospital for a hip replacement operation. He underwent an angioplasty but was not administered heparin during the procedure. Postoperatively, he developed a blood clot and died from a myocardial infarction. An inquest was held to determine the cause of death and prior to the Inquest, the Trust admitted the failure to administer Heparin was negligent. DOC.TI: 'WHAT DOESN'T KILL YOU MAKES YOU; STRONGER'; Two county students TO SERVE as representatives for Hurley Benefit Ball
DOC.TEXT: By Sarah Schuch Credit: sschuch@mlive.com GENESEE COUNTY -- One is a Kearsley High School student, the other a Flint International Academy seventh-grader, but one thing they have in common is they both have had to fight for a normal life. Austin Perez, 16, of Genesee Township, has struggled with severe asthma most of his life. April LaGrone, 12, of Flint, has been learning how to balance life with Type I juvenile diabetes since 2006. Because of their stories, their time spent in Hurley Medical Center's pediatric department and their support and promotion of the Children's Miracle Network and Hurley's Children Hospital, Austin and April are being recognized at this year's See Hurley, A2 Continued from A1 Hurley Benefit Ball, which raises money for the children's hospital. "It's a proud moment. You just know you've come through so much," Austin said in an interview with The Flint Journal. "I think it makes you a stronger person. ... Some people don't truly understand what (asthma) does, how it changes your life." Austin was born with underdeveloped lungs. For more than a year, he was treated for upper respiratory infections, one after the other, before he was diagnosed with having asthma at age 3. It was hard for him to breathe, making it difficult for him to do much of anything else, including walk, play outside or even tie his shoes. During his first time sledding at age 5, he collapsed at the bottom of the hill and had to be rushed to the hospital. From age 6 to 10, Austin's asthma was at its worst. He was on 11 medications. Between October and March, it was almost a guarantee that he would be in the hospital regularly. Two attacks were so bad Austin almost died. He spent most of his time inside, away from anything that could create an attack. "I pretty much lived in the hospital. I had someone doing everything for me, carrying me. ... In some way, I feel like I missed out on childhood a little," Austin said. "It kind of just made you feel bad. ... Why me? You felt left behind that you couldn't do what the other kids could do." Susan Perez, Austin's mother, said it was a scary time for the family. Just walking out into the cold could send Austin into an attack. He and his family were given guidance and education on how to control and deal with his asthma. At age 10, Austin found a medication to help with allergies and asthma. It dramatically reduced his symptoms. In fact, he can't remember the last time he's been to the hospital past age 10. But the journey has left him a different person, his mother said. "I was afraid to let him out of the house," said Perez, adding how proud she was of how he handled it all. "(The whole experience) made him a really responsible kid. It made him grow up fast." Now he gets a shot at a normal life, Austin said. "It's amazing. I've tried new things, got to try new sports," he said, thanking the staff at Hurley for all their help and support. "Now I've got my goals on what I'm going to achieve. I can do anything and it's awesome." Austin and April were chosen to be representatives at the upcoming ball by various clinical staff at Hurley, said Hurley Spokeswoman Ilene Cantor. And they are proud to have them tell their stories and offer inspiration to others, she said. Dealing with diabetes April's story started around Christmas 2006. She was 8 and had symptoms of what she thought was the flu -- fatigue, weight loss, frequent urination and a constant thirst. Within a month, April had lost 5 to 7 pounds, and she went to see a doctor. Her blood sugar level was so high it didn't even register in blood tests. She was diagnosed with a disease that would stick with her for the rest of her life -- Type I juvenile diabetes, a disease in which the body does not properly produce insulin. She spent the next three days in Hurley's Pediatric Intensive Care Unit and two more in the pediatric area there. "I was feeling horrible. I didn't know what was going on. ... I couldn't get over it," said April, who is now in the homebound program at Flint International Academy. "I felt overwhelmed because I was 8 years old. I wanted to be carefree, and now I had all this responsibility of dealing with this disease." Her life would never be the same. April now checks her blood sugar four to six times a day and gives herself insulin at least four times a day or uses an insulin pump. She had trained herself to count carbohydrates and be careful of everything she eats. Eating sweets in moderation is particularly important. Too much physical activity can be dangerous for her blood sugar, as well. Her blood sugar fluctuates constantly. She never knows when it's going to be too high or too low. Twice she has gone into diabetic ketoacidosis, when she had too much acid in her blood and had to be rushed to the hospital. "When I have high blood sugar, I'm tired, thirsty, irritated. (Diabetic ketoacidosis) is like that times 10. My heart beats really fast. Sometimes I vomit, have rapid breathing, burning sensation in my chest," April said. "It was the worst feeling in the world. I thought I was going to die. I thought I would never feel normal again. It's hard to feel normal when you have diabetes. It's up and down. It's a roller coaster." Tonya LaGrone, April's mother, said it has been difficult to watch her daughter go through so much, but she is proud of how she's handled it. "Despite all her challenges, she's been courageous. She's a fighter," LaGrone said. "She still likes to project that she's a normal teenager." April said she has grown through the experience and hopes she can help others in the same situation. She's proud to represent the children's hospital at the upcoming ball, she said. "I've had to grow up really fast. I have all of these responsibilities of how to take care of myself," April said. "No kid wants to be diagnosed with a disease they will have for the rest of their life. But it could be worse. ... (I want kids with diabetes to know) you can get through this. I thought it was the end of the world. But you can get through this. "What doesn't kill you makes you stronger."

DOC.TI: UPDATE: Roche Lifts Hostile Illumina Cash Offer to $51 Per Share
DOC.TEXT: -- New offer values Illumina at around $6.6 billion -- Illumina tells its shareholders to defer action -- Analysts say Roche's new bid could bring a deal closer -- Offer expires on April 20, two days after Illumina's AGM (Adds Illumina's comment in paragraph 4, details from Roche's statement, analysts comments and background) By Marta Falconi Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES ZURICH -(Dow Jones)- Roche Holding AG (ROG.VX) Thursday increased its unsolicited offer to buy U.S. gene-sequencing company Illumina Inc. (ILMN) to $51 per share, valuing the company at more than $6.5 billion. The Swiss drug maker raised its offer from $44.50, saying that based on discussions with Illumina shareholders "we have seen interest to accelerate the takeover process." "All other terms and conditions of the tender offer remain unchanged," Roche said in a statement. Illumina responded by saying its shareholders should "take no action at this time." Roche original $5.7 billion offer for the San Diego-based company, made in January, met fierce resistance from the target company which rejected it as being too low. In a letter to Illumina Chief Executive Jay Flatley on Thursday, Roche Chairman Franz Humer said the Swiss drug maker wants a negotiated transaction with Illumina, but added: If you continue to decline to negotiate with us, we will have no choice but to continue our effort to effect a transaction unilaterally. "We hope that you will agree that our new price presents a very attractive opportunity to your shareholders," Humer added. Analysts said Roche's sweetened offer had been expected, adding that it reflects Illumina's current share price level and thus may bring an agreed deal closer. "Roche talked to some shareholders and sees a possibility that there's interest in the offer at this price," said David Kaegi, a Zurich-based analyst with Bank Sarasin, who has a buy rating on Roche. Kaegi said Thursday's move is consistent with Roche's past M&A strategy and the company's history of long and bumpy takeover battles. "To offer something about 20% lower than what you finally want to pay follows a script in these types of transactions," he said. Roche has been increasing pressure on Illumina's management to give in, extending the offer's acceptance period twice, after it launched its bid last January. It now runs to 6 p.m. New York time, or 2200 GMT, on April 20 -- two days after Illumina's shareholder AGM at which Roche is aiming to gain control of the Illumina board. Roche said earlier this month that it is also willing to consider "other options," should the deal fail over price. Friday's new bid represents a 15% premium to Roche's initial offer of $44.50 per share and about 88% over Illumina's stock price mid-December before rumors of the potential transaction first surfaced. "The sweetened terms represent a total value of $6.6 billion, and we estimate the value Illumina's business on a stand alone business to be around $43-$44 per share," says analyst Andrew Weiss with Swiss private bank Vontobel, which has a buy rate on Roche. "Hence, it is paying about a $1 billion premium, though we believe Illumina is a great fit for Roche and could enable them to develop more targeted therapies in the future," he said. The acquisition of Illumina, which makes gene-decoding machines, is a crucial step for Roche on the path to develop targeted therapies, matching drugs to those patients who benefit most from them and helping curb health care costs. Personalized medicine is expected to play an increasingly important role in cancer therapy, where Roche is a market leader. -By Marta Falconi, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 8043; marta.falconi@dowjones.com (Sten Stovall contributed to this article.) DOC.TI: Tigers' 2008 Final Four banner tucked away in R.C. Johnson's closet
DOC.TEXT: March 30--Banished from the FedExForum rafters in controversy, the banner commemorating the University of Memphis' 2008 Final Four run now rests in a less glamorous place: a storage closet in athletic director R.C. Johnson's office. "This closet, it has one key to it," Johnson said, "and I have the key." Such is the peculiar status of the highest-profile memento of the Tigers' modern-day pinnacle. Earned from their 38-win season in 2007-08 that ended a Mario Chalmers 3-pointer shy of the national title, the banner hung for two seasons in FedExForum, cozy between the 2007 Elite Eight banner and the 2009 Sweet Sixteen flag. But when the school lost its appeal of sanctions in March 2010, that meant the end of its 2008 buddy, dealt a life sentence in the darkness of a campus closet. At least, we'll have to take Johnson's word for it. The UofM interprets its sanctions from the NCAA as meaning that the banner cannot be photographed, which means The Commercial Appeal's request to do so this week was turned down. The pertinent line from the NCAA's infractions appeals committee report in 2010: "Any public reference to these vacated contests, including the appearance in the 2008 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Championship shall be removed from athletics department stationery, banners displayed in public areas and any other forum in which they appear." Most of the life of Memphis' banner had been spent in another nondescript storage area within the university's athletics office building on Normal. But there remained a concern that a zealous Tiger fan would stumble upon it one day and abscond with it. "We've got all sorts of fans who would want it," Johnson said. So when Johnson obtained this new storage space last year, associate athletic director Bob Winn suggested that the banner be placed there. Johnson agreed. Memphis is not without precedent. Michigan's 1992 and 1993 Final Four banners, as well as a 1998 Big Ten banner, are stored at the Bentley Historical Library on campus, spokesman Dave Ablauf said. Interest in the banner's location tends to spike this time of year, as the NCAA Tournament offers a reminder of the anniversary, Johnson said. "We get fans that call, or whatever, they start reminiscing about 2008," Johnson said. "Of course now, with (the Kentucky success of former coach) John (Calipari), that just accentuates it." Johnson was hopeful that when the Tigers go off probation on Aug. 19 that the banner could find a more prominent home. Not the FedExForum rafters, but perhaps the Hardaway Hall of Fame down the street. More of a historic document, not a show-off. But Sheri Lipman, the school's legal counsel, says that won't happen. As long as the wins are vacated, the banner will have to remain out of plain sight. -- Kyle Veazey: (901) 529-2799 ----- ___ (c)2012 The Commercial Appeal (Memphis, Tenn.) DOC.TI: Amerikanske møder om fedme fik Novo til at tage på
DOC.TEXT: markedsoversigt Novo Nordisk igen trækhesten i et pænt resultat for det danske C20-indeks. Efter en sløv start på dagen kom der fut under Novo-aktien, som blev løftet fra et niveau omkring 776 kr. til en slutkurs på 794,50 kr. - en stigning på 1,6 pct. Aktien vejer omkring 40 pct. i C20-indekset og var dermed en stor årsag til, at det kunne slutte 0,75 pct. højere i indeksniveau 449,64, mens stort set alle andre europæiske markeder faldt. Novo Nordisk er i fokus, fordi de amerikanske sundhedsmyndigheder i disse dage diskuterer krav til kommende lægemidler til behandling af fedme. Novo Nordisk har diabetesmidlet Victoza på vej som fedmebehandling i de kommende år. Carlsberg havde også en fremgangsrig dag på børsen og lukkede 1,5 pct. højere i kurs 455,70. Bryggeriaktien blev dermed blandt dagens vindere i C20 og kunne sende sin tak til lovende tal og fremtidsudsigter fra kinesiske Chongqing Brewery, som Carlsberg ejer en stor aktiepost i. PNE Wind, der står for Gode Wind I-projektet, fortalte i går, at Vestas blev fravalgt, da selskabets store offshoresatsning, en mølle på 7 MW, stadig er for langt væk. Kontrakten på 84 af Vestas' 3 MW-møller til Gode Wind II-projektet lever dog fortsat, understreger PNE Winds kommunikationschef, Rainer Heinsohn, over for Ritzau Finans. Vestas-aktien lukkede 0,1 pct. højere i 58,20 kr. A. P. Møller -Mærsk-aktierne tilbragte hele dagen i rødt, og B-aktien sluttede i et fald på 0,4 pct. til kurs 42.840. FLSmidth-aktien er nu faldet 11 af de seneste 13 handelsdage og har nu har krydset den tekniske grænse ved kurs 400. Ingeniøraktien lukkede 2,3 pct. nede i kurs 390,80. Små udsving i obligationer De europæiske obligationer viste små udsving onsdag med en lille tendens til faldende renter, især ud på eftermiddagen. En vellykket italiensk auktion over seksmånederspapirer gav lidt pusterum, men det gældspressede land skal til en større eksamen i dag. De danske statspapirer lå relativt stille det meste af dagen, men efter et skuffende nøgletal fra USA vendte renterne pilen nedad på eftermiddagen. Således lukkede den toneangivende tiårige obligation, 3-21' eren, i en rente på 1,85 pct., et fald på 5 basispoint mod tirsdag. På de andre danske papirer var der tale om fald i lignende niveauer. I Tyskland og Storbritannien var der lignende rentefald på omtrent 5 basispoint på de tiårige papirer, mens Spanien og Italiens renter viste lidt mindre fald i renten. Ved en auktion over italienske statsobligationer med seksmåneders løbetid blev der solgt papirer for 8,5 mia. euro til en rente på 1,119 pct. sammenlignet med 1,202 pct. en måned før. De korte renter holdes dog kunstigt lave af Den Europæiske Centralbanks store likviditetstildeling til bankerne, mener Nordeas analytiker Carsten Rasmussen, der peger på auktionen i dag som en større indikator for støvlelandet. »Den store prøve på markedets tiltro til den italienske stats evne til at afdrage på sin gæld kommer først i morgen ( i dag, red.), hvor man håber på at sælge op til 8,25 milliarder euro i 5-årige og tiårige statsobligationer«, skrev Carsten Rasmussen i en note. erhverv@pol.dk

DOC.TI: When it comes to the generation gap, respect is a two-way street; Boris Johnson wants to force youngsters to behave well on public transport. Martin Hesp supports the move but says we should try to find why some children have lost respect
DOC.TEXT: The shame is that this was needed in the first place. How many opinion pieces could I have concluded with those words in the ten years I've been a columnist for this newspaper? Hundreds, I should think - and now I'm at it again. I do so in light of the news that teenagers will be told to "stand up for their elders" on public transport (in London at least) - or risk losing their right to free travel. At first glance you can't help but applaud London Mayor Boris Johnson who this week unveiled plans to make youngsters sign a "courtesy pledge" - a promise to behave in a respectful manner when travelling in the capital. Who doesn't detest the selfish, yobbish behaviour that seems to have overtaken the old-fashioned world of good manners? Of course, if you were only ever to read certain newspapers of a "s h o ck -horror" bent, you'd probably believe the world is filled with nasty kids who wouldn't dream of standing up so an older person could take their seat. But on a couple of recent trips to London I've been delighted to see youngsters doing just that on the Tube trains. Not sullenly or reluctantly - nor because someone had pointed out an old man or a pregnant woman was having to stand while they reposed on their youthful backsides - but instantly and helpfully. On the other hand, I'm no fool and certainly don't see life through rose-coloured spectacles. I know today's youth doesn't embrace that strange and somewhat ephemeral concept of "respect" in the way people used to. But why have things like respect and courtesy been on the wane? If you ask someone of my age they might well tell you that they can recall when the requirement for respect was too powerful, demanding and all-embracing. I spent my formative years in that tidechanging period of the 1960s and 70s when unquestioning, old fashioned, Victorian-style respect was beginning to run out of steam. It demanded that you kowtowed to your elders all the time - without ever questioning why - even if some of those stationed "above" you in life were bounders, morons or idiots. The rot in the great tree of respect began to grow in the First World War when some bounders, morons and even idiots were put in charge of fighting troops, thanks solely to their position in a classobsessed society - with horrific and deadly results. The Second World War eroded the "re s p e c t -yo u rbetters" scheme of things more - and by the 1960s the idea that you had to bow to certain other elements in society (ie your elders or anyone in a superior financial position) was well and truly on the slide. By the 1970s we rebellious youngsters were more likely to cock-a-snook at just about anyone or anything. The older folk around us simply couldn't understand the crazy, thrill-seeking, fun-obsessed new world of youth - and likewise the kids couldn't understand the fast disappearing era when duty, reverence and unquestioning compliance had meant far more than a person's happiness. Throw in the later "there's no such thing as society" ideas of Margaret Thatcher's gang and the subsequent "importance of individual choice" politics thereafter - and what have you got? A society that tends to think "me" first - and "you and everyone else" a distant second, if at all. It's certainly a society that has lost the will to put community and universal responsibility high on every agenda. You only have to look at the present Government's present idea that our amazing, fragile and hugely vital environment comes second to temporary financial gain to know that. When the likes of Boris Johnson, and the rest of us for that matter, see some skulking youth squatting selfishly on a seat when someone more deserving is left to stand, we should not be looking at two individuals in a Tube train - we should be seeing a vast social disaster zone and wondering what to do about it. I have no problem with the Mayor of London taking steps to force ideas of respect and courtesy on young people - but I do think it's a bit like seeing someone take an aspirin for toothache when the offending molar obviously needs major root canal work. Children need to be taught about their part in society - what they can expect from it, and what it can expect from them - from an early age. The problem is that new generations learn best when led by example - so perhaps we so-called "elders" need to clean up our act. In a world where shockhorror media targets the lowest common denominator; where TV executives and celebrities seem to exalt "lad" behaviour and other unthinking buffoonery above culture and good taste; and where politicians are quite happy to hijack our one-andonly life-giving countryside in return for a fast buck - what do we expect our kids to think?'Who doesn't detest the yobbish behaviour that seems to have overtaken the oldfashioned world of good manners?'

"For example, I can say to you, with absolute confidence, that you're unlikely to see me in Speedos," he said. But he said both Ms Gillard and Treasurer Wayne Swan had said some "nasty things" about him in the past. "For me it's water off a duck's back. It's no revelation that I'm a fully sized guy," he said. "Frankly when you pass comment about someone's weight or something like that I think it says more about you than it does about them."

DOC.TI: Fyringsdrama skader Dong
DOC.TEXT: DONG Anders Eldrup har »tilsidesat« og »misligholdt« sine forpligtelser som direktør, konkluderer en advokatundersøgelse. Hovedpersonen vil fortsætte sagen ved en voldgift og retter nu en skarp kritik mod bestyrelsesformand Fritz Schur. Der var tale om en magtdemonstration, da bestyrelsesformand Fritz Schur i går satte trumf på i fyringssagen om den statsejede energigigants topchef, Anders Eldrup. Først fik han politikernes opbakning, og så gik han til pressemøde flankeret af næstformand Lars Nørby Johansen, Novodirektør Lars Rieben og advokat Mariann Norrbom og fremlagde resultaterne af den ventede advokatundersøgelse. Den konkluderer i utvetydige vendinger, at Anders Eldrup har misligholdt sin kontrakt ved at give en lille gruppe nøglemedarbejdere lukrative løn-og bonusvilkår - uden at informere bestyrelsen. Konklusionen blev blåstemplet af Kammeradvokaten Den højdramatiske sag efterlader imidlertid Danmarks vigtigste energiselskab med alvorlige imageproblemer, vurderer en ekspert. »Hele sagen efterlader et Dong med alvorlige ridser i lakken og et blakket image. Det har på ingen måde været en god sag for et selskab, der måske i forvejen ikke var særligt populær blandt kunderne«, siger Mogens Rüdiger, professor på Aalborg Universitet og forfatter til en bog om Dong. I Dongs bestyrelse erkender man, at fyringssagen ikke har været god for virksomheden, der spiller en nøglerolle i bestræbelsen på at omstille det danske samfund til grøn energi. »På vindmølleområdet er der klart sket et imagetab, som skal rettes op«, siger næstformand Lars Nørby Johansen. På et pressemøde i går kom det frem, at den nu fyrede topdirektør reelt har været udsat for pression fra fire nøglemedarbejdere, der angiveligt har ageret som en samlet gruppe og igen og igen opsøgte Eldrup og pressede ham til stadigt mere lukrative løn-og ansættelsesvilkår under truslen om ellers at forlade selskabet til fordel for konkurrenterne. »Jeg har aldrig set noget lignende. Det er helt uhørt, det der er foregået. Det er kommet ud på et skråplan, det her. De pågældende medarbejdere har kunnet presse direktøren, og så har det udviklet sig til en skrue uden ende«, sagde bestyrelsesmedlem og administrerende direktør i Novo Nordisk, Lars Rieben. Samlet konkluderer advokatundersøgelsen, at Anders Eldrup har »tilsidesat« og »misligholdt« sine forpligtelser som direktør ved gennem syv år at have givet de fire centrale medarbejdere meget store beløb i godtgørelser og bonus, som lå »langt ud over« Dongs generelle retningslinjer, uden at have orienteret bestyrelsen om det. Ifølge næstformand Lars Nørby Johansen har Anders Eldrup, ved ikke at gå til bestyrelsen med nøglemedarbejdernes krav, reelt udøvet en form for selvtægt. »Han burde være gået til os, i stedet skete der noget, man bedst kan betegne som selvtægt«, sagde han. Anders Eldrup er stærkt uenig i advokatundersøgelsen, som han kalder et »partsindlæg«. Han vil derfor have sagen behandlet ved en voldgift, blandt andet fordi bestyrelsen på baggrund af rapporten har besluttet at nægte ham hans fulde fratrædelsesgodtgørelse. Mens Eldrup kræver 17 millioner kroner, er bestyrelsen kun parat til at give ham 6. I sådan en sag skal man ikke afskrive Anders Eldrups chancer, vurderer Peter Breum, partner i advokatfirmaet Elmer & Partnere. »En voldgiftsag vil tegne et noget mere nuanceret billede, end det der kommer frem i undersøgelsen«, siger han. Efter fjorten dages tavshed retter Eldrup i dag i Politiken desuden en stærk kritik af bestyrelsesformand Fritz Schurs ledelse af det statslige selskab: »Al kontakt mellem ejeren (finansministeren, red.) og selskabet er foregået gennem Schur. Det er helt usædvanligt. Jeg har været direktør for statens langt, langt største selskab uden nogen sinde at drøfte med ejeren, hvordan han ønskede selskabet udviklet. Schur har monopol på, hvad ejeren får at vide, og hvad der blev fortalt tilbage til bestyrelsen«, siger Anders Eldrup, der oplyser, at han - da Fritz Schur blev formand for seks år siden - fik forbud mod at tale med ministeren, departementschefen eller embedsmændene i øvrigt i Finansministeriet. »Det var kafkask og skabte et miljø, hvor mistillid trives«, siger Eldrup og understreger, at han som direktør i Dong ikke har overtrådt nogen regler. Dong's kommunikationschef, Karsten Anker Petersen, skriver i en mail til Politiken, at bestyrelsesformand Fritz Schur »ikke ønsker at bidrage til konflikt til skade for Dong«, og at bestyrelsesformanden »derfor ikke har nogen kommentarer«. Også Finansminister Bjaren Corydon (S) afviser at forholde sig til den fyrede direktørs kritik: »Jeg har ikke nogen kommentar til den debat, der kører i mellem Anders Eldrup og bestyrelsen i Dong. Jeg har tillid til bestyrelsen og bakker op om dens beslutning«, siger han. niels.fastrup@pol.dk . DOC.TI: Hurley Student ambassadors tell of journeys with diabetes, asthma
DOC.TEXT: Continued from A1 Hurley Benefit Ball, which raises money for the children's hospital. "It's a proud moment. You just know you've come through so much," Austin said in an interview with The Flint Journal. "I think it makes you a stronger person. ... Some people don't truly understand what (asthma) does, how it changes your life." Austin was born with underdeveloped lungs. For more than a year, he was treated for upper respiratory infections, one after the other, before he was diagnosed with having asthma at age 3. It was hard for him to breathe, making it difficult for him to do much of anything else, including walk, play outside or even tie his shoes. During his first time sledding at age 5, he collapsed at the bottom of the hill and had to be rushed to the hospital. From age 6 to 10, Austin's asthma was at its worst. He was on 11 medications. Between October and March, it was almost a guarantee that he would be in the hospital regularly. Two attacks were so bad Austin almost died. He spent most of his time inside, away from anything that could create an attack. "I pretty much lived in the hospital. I had someone doing everything for me, carrying me. ... In some way, I feel like I missed out on childhood a little," Austin said. "It kind of just made you feel bad. ... Why me? You felt left behind that you couldn't do what the other kids could do." Susan Perez, Austin's mother, said it was a scary time for the family. Just walking out into the cold could send Austin into an attack. He and his family were given guidance and education on how to control and deal with his asthma. At age 10, Austin found a medication to help with allergies and asthma. It dramatically reduced his symptoms. In fact, he can't remember the last time he's been to the hospital past age 10. But the journey has left him a different person, his mother said. "I was afraid to let him out of the house," said Perez, adding how proud she was of how he handled it all. "(The whole experience) made him a really responsible kid. It made him grow up fast." Now he gets a shot at a normal life, Austin said. "It's amazing. I've tried new things, got to try new sports," he said, thanking the staff at Hurley for all their help and support. "Now I've got my goals on what I'm going to achieve. I can do anything and it's awesome." Austin and April were chosen to be representatives at the upcoming ball by various clinical staff at Hurley, said Hurley spokeswoman Ilene Cantor. And they are proud to have them tell their stories and offer inspiration to others, she said. Dealing with diabetes April's story started around Christmas 2006. She was 8 and had symptoms of what she thought was the flu -- fatigue, weight loss, frequent urination and a constant thirst. Within a month, April had lost 5 to 7 pounds, and she went to see a doctor. Her blood sugar level was so high it didn't even register in blood tests. She was diagnosed with a disease that would stick with her for the rest of her life -- Type I juvenile diabetes, a disease in which the body does not properly produce insulin. She spent the next three days in Hurley's Pediatric Intensive Care Unit and two more in the pediatric area there. "I was feeling horrible. I didn't know what was going on. ... I couldn't get over it," said April, who is now in the homebound program at Flint International Academy. "I felt overwhelmed because I was 8 years old. I wanted to be carefree, and now I had all this responsibility of dealing with this disease." Her life would never be the same. April now checks her blood sugar four to six times a day and gives herself insulin at least four times a day or uses an insulin pump. She had trained herself to count carbohydrates and be careful of everything she eats. Eating sweets in moderation is particularly important. Too much physical activity can be dangerous for her blood sugar, as well. Her blood sugar fluctuates constantly. She never knows when it's going to be too high or too low. Twice she has gone into diabetic ketoacidosis, when she had too much acid in her blood and had to be rushed to the hospital. "When I have high blood sugar, I'm tired, thirsty, irritated. (Diabetic ketoacidosis) is like that times 10. My heart beats really fast. Sometimes I vomit, have rapid breathing, burning sensation in my chest," April said. "It was the worst feeling in the world. I thought I was going to die. I thought I would never feel normal again. It's hard to feel normal when you have diabetes. It's up and down. It's a roller coaster." Tonya LaGrone, April's mother, said it has been difficult to watch her daughter go through so much, but she is proud of how she's handled it. "Despite all her challenges, she's been courageous. She's a fighter," LaGrone said. "She still likes to project that she's a normal teenager." April said she has grown through the experience and hopes she can help others in the same situation. She's proud to represent the children's hospital at the upcoming ball, she said. "I've had to grow up really fast. I have all of these responsibilities of how to take care of myself," April said. "No kid wants to be diagnosed with a disease they will have for the rest of their life. But it could be worse. ... (I want kids with diabetes to know) you can get through this. I thought it was the end of the world. But you can get through this. "What doesn't kill you makes you stronger."

DOC.TI: Boris on right track with new era of bus respect; Boris Johnson wants to force youngsters to behave well on public transport. Martin Hesp supports the move but says we should try to find out why some children have lost respect in the first place
DOC.TEXT: The shame is that this scheme to force youngsters on public transport to behave well was needed in the first place. How many opinion pieces could I have concluded with those words in the ten years I've been a columnist? Hundreds, I should think - and now I'm at it again. I do so in light of the news that teenagers will be told to "stand up for their elders" on public transport (in London at least) - or risk losing their right to free travel. At first glance you can't help but applaud London Mayor Boris Johnson who this week unveiled plans to make youngsters sign a "courtesy pledge" - a promise to behave in a respectful manner when travelling. Who doesn't detest the selfish, yobbish behaviour that seems to have overtaken the old-fashioned world of good manners? Of course, if you were only ever to read certain newspapers of a "s h o ck -horror" bent, you'd probably believe the world is filled with nasty kids who wouldn't dream of standing up so an older person could take their seat. But on a couple of recent trips to London I've been delighted to see youngsters doing just that on the Tube trains. Not sullenly or reluctantly - nor because someone had pointed out an old man or a pregnant woman was having to stand while they reposed on their youthful backsides - but instantly and helpfully. On the other hand, I'm no fool and certainly don't see life through rose-coloured spectacles. I know today's youth doesn't embrace that strange and somewhat ephemeral concept of "respect" in the way people used to. But why have things like respect and courtesy been on the wane? If you ask someone of my age they might well tell you that they can recall when the requirement for respect was too powerful, demanding and all-embracing. I spent my formative years in that tidechanging period of the 1960s and 70s when unquestioning, old fashioned, Victorian-style respect was beginning to run out of steam. It demanded that you kowtowed to your elders all the time - without ever questioning why - even if some of those stationed "above" you in life were bounders, morons or idiots. The rot in the great tree of respect began to grow in the First World War when some bounders, morons and even idiots were put in charge of fighting troops, thanks solely to their position in a classobsessed society - with horrific and deadly results. The Second World War eroded the "re s p e c t -yo u rbetters" scheme of things more - and by the 1960s the idea that you had to bow to certain other elements in society (i.e. your elders or anyone in a superior financial position) was well and truly on the slide. By the 1970s we rebellious youngsters were more likely to cock-a-snook at just about anyone or anything. The older folk around us simply couldn't understand the crazy, thrillseeking, fun-obsessed new world of youth - and likewise the kids couldn't understand the fast disappearing era when duty, reverence and unquestioning compliance had meant far more than a person's happiness. Throw in the later "there's no such thing as society" ideas of Margaret Thatcher's gang and the subsequent "importance of individual choice" politics thereafter - and what have you got? A society that tends to think "me" first - and "you and everyone else" a distant second, if at all. It's certainly a society that has lost the will to put community and universal responsibility high on every agenda. You only have to look at the present Government's present idea that our amazing, fragile and hugely vital environment comes second to temporary financial gain to know that. When the likes of Boris Johnson, and the rest of us for that matter, see some skulking youth squatting selfishly on a seat when someone more deserving is left to stand, we should not be looking at two people on a bus - we should be seeing a social disaster zone and wondering what to do about it. I have no problem with the Mayor of London taking steps to force ideas of respect and courtesy on young people - but I do think it's a bit like seeing someone take an aspirin for toothache when the offending molar obviously needs some major root canal work. Children need to be taught about their part in society - what they can expect from it, and what it can expect from them - from an early age. The problem is that new generations learn best when led by example - so perhaps we so-called "elders" need to clean up our act. In a world where shockhorror media targets the lowest common denominator; where TV executives and celebrities seem to exalt "lad" behaviour and other unthinking buffoonery above culture and good taste; and where politicians are quite happy to hijack our one-andonly life-giving countryside in return for a fast buck - what do we expect our kids to think?'Why have things like respect and courtesy been on the wane?'

DOC.TI: Dongs lønkomité blev advaret i 2009
DOC.TEXT: pressemøde Dongs fyrede topchef forsøgte at sløre oplysninger om lønfrås i notat til bestyrelsen i 2009. Alligevel burde bestyrelsen have lugtet lunten, mener ekspert. Dongs bestyrelse blev tilbage i 2009 orienteret om, at visse af selskabets nøglemedarbejdere havde helt særlige løn-og bonusvilkår, der rakte langt ud over selskabets generelle retningslinjer for lønvilkår for de ansatte. Det fremgår af Kammeradvokatens advokatundersøgelse af forholdene i Dong, som blev offentliggjort i går. Spørgsmålet om bestyrelsens kendskab til de usædvanlige lønforhold for fire af den nu fyrede topchef Anders Eldrups nærmeste medarbejdere er helt centralt i sagen. Bestyrelsens hovedargument for at skille sig af med Eldrup er nemlig, at Eldrup undlod at informere bestyrelsens vederlagskomité om de usædvanlige forhold, som han skulle. Men ifølge Kammeradvokatens undersøgelse modtog komitéen i august 2009 et notat, hvoraf det blandt andet fremgik: »I enkelttilfælde er der indført særskilte kompensationselementer for nøglepersoner. Det kan for eksempel være i form af fastholdelsesordninger, særlige performanceafhængige ydelser, kompensation for flere jobfunktioner m. v.«, fremgår det MICHAEL LUND af Kammeradvokatens undersøgelse. »Vederlagskomiteen har herved haft en vis anledning til at stille spørgsmål til det nærmere indhold af disse særordninger«, konkluderer Kammeradvokaten. Komiteen består blandt andet af bestyrelsesformand Fritz Schur og næstformand Lars Nørby Johansen, der flere gange har nægtet at kende til forholdene og har forsvaret komiteens arbejde. Men professor i ledelse ved Aalborg Universitet Per Nikolaj Bukh mener, at vederlagskomiteen her forsømte en åbenlys mulighed for at tage sagen op: »Her havde det været oplagt for bestyrelsen at spørge mere ind til emnet. Hvad er de største lønninger, hvilke lønninger afviger mest fra normalen, hvor mange er der tale om, er blot nogle af de mest oplagte spørgsmål, de burde have stillet. Man kan nok ikke direkte sige, at vederlagskomiteen har forsømt sin pligt, men det havde været smart at stille disse spørgsmål dengang«, siger han. Kammeradvokaten konkluderer overordnet, at Anders Eldrup forsømte at orientere bestyrelsen korrekt og fyldestgørende, og at fyringen af ham derfor var helt efter bogen. Desuden påpeger advokaterne, at Eldrup aktivt rettede i de afsnit i 2009-notatet, der omtalte de pågældende nøglemedarbejderes lønforhold, så visse afslørende detaljer om lønforholdene aldrig nåede bestyrelsen. På et pressemøde i Dongs bygninger i Gentofte i går afviste bestyrelsesmedlemmerne og deres advokater da også, at vederlagskomiteen reagerede forkert på 2009-notatet. Tværtimod forsøgte komiteen at indhente oplysninger om løn-og bonusforhold for det lavere lederniveau, lød det: »Og de oplysninger får vi aldrig, selv om vi stiller spørgsmålet«, lød det fra Lars Nørby Johansen. Hvorfor fulgte I ikke op på det? »Vi fik det kun oplyst som gennemsnitsløn«, supplerede Fritz Schur. Og det var I tilfredse med? »Som der står klart og tydeligt i Kammeradvokatens redegørelse, så er det op til en direktør at give fyldestgørende oplysninger til bestyrelsen. Det har han tilsidesat«, konstaterede Fritz Schur. »Mit indtryk er, at vederlagskomiteen i Dong har fungeret, som den gør de fleste andre steder«, supplerede Lars Nørby. Den tredje repræsentant fra bestyrelsen, administrerende direktør i Novo Nordisk, Lars Rebien Sørensen, gav sin fulde opbakning til vederlagskomiteen. »Sådan fungerer det også i andre virksomheder. Jeg orienterer selv min bestyrelse, hvis bare jeg giver en måneds ekstra bonus til en ansat, netop for ikke at ende i et mistillidsforhold til bestyrelsen«. På pressemødet kommenterede Novochefen for første gang balladen i energiselskabet, siden striden brød ud, og han gentog, hvad hans bestyrelseskolleger har sagt gennem de seneste uger om lønforholdene for de fire medarbejdere: »Jeg har aldrig set noget lignende. Det er helt uhørt, det, der er foregået. De pågældende medarbejdere har kunnet presse direktøren, og så har det udviklet sig til en skrue uden ende«. Ingen grøn uenighed Et tilbagevendende emne på pressemødet var de seneste dages historier om, at fyringen skulle bunde i en uenighed om hastigheden af Dongs grønne strategi. At Fritz Schur skulle have ønsket at skaffe sig af med Eldrup, fordi direktøren satsede for aggressivt på blandt andet havvindmøller. Og at Eldrup skulle have konkrete planer om helt at udskille Dongs afdeling for vindenergi i et nyt selskab. Men at det skulle spille en rolle, blev afvist. »Det omtalte projekt er slet ikke forelagt bestyrelsen. Vi har kun fået nogle spredte notater og har selv bedt om nogle. Det er slet ikke grydeklart over for bestyrelsen, så den ville kunne træffe en beslutning på det«, sagde Fritz Schur. Både Rebien og Nørby understregede, at bestyrelsen støttede alle dele af Anders Eldrups hidtidige strategi. »Der er ikke engang en uenighed om tempoet. Der er vedtaget en strategi, og den fastholder vi naturligvis. Den finansieringsmodel, der er lavet med blandt andre pensionskasser, synes vi er fantastisk spændende, og den vil vi gerne fortsætte med. Der er ingen uenighed, og det var slet ikke inde i overvejelserne omkring fyringen«, sagde Nørby Johansen. michael.lund@pol.dk Fakta: Dong-sagen dag for dag I gennem den seneste måned har der været blæst om det statsejede energiselskab Dong Energy Bestyrelsesformand i Dong, Fritz Schur, får et tip om, at Anders Eldrup har bevilget flere medarbejdere særlige lønforhold. Bestyrelsen er ikke orienteret og undersøger derfor sagen. Fritz Schur orienterer Finansministeriet om, at der pågår en undersøgelse i Dong Energy. Fritz Schur hyrer advokatfirmaet Norrbom Vinding til at lave en undersøgelse af forholdene. Fritz Schur orienterer bestyrelsen. Bestyrelsen er enig om at afskedige Eldrup. Schur forelægger beslutningen for Eldrup. De aftaler, at Eldrup formelt selv siger op, mod udbetaling af fuldt fratrædelsesbeløb. Afskedigelsen bliver offentliggjort uden begrundelse og efter gensidig overenskomst. Aftrædelsesviklkår er endeligt aftalt. Økonomidirektør Carsten Krogsgaard konstitueres som adm. direktør. Dong Energy oplyser, at Anders Eldrups afskedigelse skyldes, at bestyrelsen har mistet tilliden til direktøren. En advokatundersøgelse skal blandt andet fastslå, om Anders Eldrup skal have hele sin opsigelsesløn på 17 mio. kr. Bestyrelsesformand Fritz Schur forklarer på et pressemøde, at en af Anders Eldrups medarbejdere, Jakob Baruël Poulsen, har fået højere løn end Eldrup selv, og at vedkommende ved opsigelse kunne forlade Dong Energy med op til 20 mio. kr. Flere medier skriver, at en strid om Dong Energys strategi kigger bag afskedigelsen af Anders Eldrup. En uvildig advokatundersøgelse bliver offentliggjort.

DOC.TI: Nightmare vision of our brave new world? In my opinion
DOC.TEXT: I popped in to my local supermarket yesterday to buy some cigarettes and a few other bits and bobs and what a depressing experience it was. I thought the tobacco counter was closed for the day as the shutters were pulled down but the assistant told me it was in fact open but under a new Government policy tobacco products had to be hidden from view. To stave off the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal I thought I'd indulge in some comfort food but alas I couldn't get to the pizza shelves due to the presence of two new Government Anti-Obesity Attack Dogs stationed there. "Never mind", I thought to myself "I'll have a nice large hot pasty to console myself." With ninja-like stealth I made it to the hot food counter only to be told that if I wanted my pasty hot I would have to pay tax on it. I asked the assistant at what temperature a pasty breached the thermal scale and became classified as "hot" but unfortunately she didn't know and the only person with a doctorate in thermal physics was on a break. Utterly confused but not undaunted I crept towards the alcohol display with the intention of spending the few pounds in my pocket on some ale. My route took me dangerously close to the fruit and veg aisle and sure enough one of the new Government Salad Enforcement Officers tried to manhandle me towards the lettuce display but I managed to fight him off. The scene at the beers & ciders aisle left me in despair as all the affordable brands had undergone a price hike because of another Government policy! I admitted defeat and shuffled out of the supermarket only to be accosted by a shady looking chap called Dimitri who offered to sell me "genuine" doughnuts from the back of his van. Despite my lack of goods I declined the offer as I feared they were in fact Eastern European in origin and they are known to contain abnormal levels of real jam. Besides it could have been a set-up and I really didn't need a conviction for possession of Class A sugar. I couldn't even fill up the car and take myself off for a drive to cheer myself up as the tax on diesel meant that I could only afford to drive for pleasure if I had use of a ministerial limo! DOC.TI: Children's growth and development is in the balance; Food for thought on eating habits
DOC.TEXT: If it is green or looks healthy, many kids would rather skip the main course and go straight on to dessert. When it comes to healthy eating, some children are just not interested. But eating a healthy, balanced diet is key to making sure children get the nutrients they need. Try to educate kids on what health benefits certain foods can have. For example, calcium-rich foods will help them to grow strong bones. You can even "hide" the healthy foods by, for example, adding extra vegetables in pasta sauce. "Healthy eating is vital for a child's growth and development and establishing healthy eating patterns as a child paves the way to life-long healthy habits," says Jack Farrow, a fitness, nutrition and weight management coach at Fit4Fun. Jack highlights the importance of a healthy diet to avoid children becoming overweight. He says if children are obese, they tend to be obese as adults and have an increased risk of developing type-2 diabetes, joint and bone problems, hypoventilation, gall bladder disease, high blood pressure and high levels of blood fat. "The risk of obesity can be reduced by reducing the sugar and fat intake and eating more carbohydrates and fibre, along with increasing the amount of physical activity," Jack says. A balanced diet will contain lots of different foods. One important food group is calcium. "A lack of calcium in a child's diet can lead to bone conditions such as rickets and osteoporosis," Jack says. "Foods such as semi-skimmed milk, low-fat yoghurt, low-fat cheese and sardines with the bones in are all great sources of calcium. Roughly two to four servings of calcium rich food are required each day, depending on your child's age. "And remember, they also need to get out and play in the sunlight - this helps the body produce Vitamin D, which helps the body absorb the calcium properly." To make sure children are getting the nutrients they need, Jack suggests introducing children to new foods and giving them a balanced diet containing carbohydrates, protein, fibre, vitamins and minerals. "If they don't like something the first time, it doesn't mean they will never like it. Try it again. A good old plate of lean meat/fish, starchy food, and a few vegetables is often hard to beat," Jack says. It's also important to get portion sizes right. Make sure your children's meals are balanced and that the portion sizes are smaller than that of a typical adult. You can find out more about Fit4Fun by e-mailing info@fit4fun.co or visiting ? If you have any concerns about your child's health or weight, see your GP. Cut out excess sugar and salt To keep your child as healthy as possible, cutting out excess salt and sugar will help. "Too much salt can cause health problems in childhood and adulthood," Jack says. "Avoid things like crisps, salty meats, salty sauces and adding more salt to food at the dinner table. This way, children won't develop the taste for it later in life. "Save sugary treat foods for holidays and parties and try to get children to snack on low-sugar and fat foods. Use trips to the park as reward, rather than sweets." By cutting down on sugary foods, it can reduce energy peak and troughs, combat mood swings, increase concentration and, of course, reduce the risk of significant weight gain.

DOC.TI: 'Treme' trickle-down; Some positive effects of the show are hard to measure, but HBO's Saturday gala will directly benefit three local artist-aid groups
DOC.TEXT: "Treme's" economic effect is tangible but sometimes hard to measure. The HBO drama spends upward of $30 million per season on the New Orleans-set-and-shot series. Local actors, technicians and musicians get some of that. The two seasons of the series to air so far have exposed a weekly average of about 2 million viewers to corners of New Orleans culture -- second-line organizations, Mardi Gras Indians, Davis Rogan -- that have never before seen such widespread attention. Some of those viewers are coming here, for the first time, to see it all for themselves. DVD boxes of the episodes -- season two is due for release April 17 -- add to the total. Digital sales of soundtrack cuts also have spiked from the HBO exposure. On Saturday, however, HBO and "Treme" will contribute in a very direct way, staging their third annual "My Darlin' New Orleans" benefit. In addition to music, food, auction items and a chance to mingle with cast and crew members, the evening offers attendees an opportunity to see and hear and taste the "Treme" effect in person. The past two such events have raised more than $175,000 total to benefit organizations that provide support and safety-net services to the people who fuel the culture that the series spotlights. This year, funds will go to Sweet Home New Orleans, the New Orleans Musicians Clinic and Assistance Foundation and The Roots of Music. Online $150 ticket sales conclude today. A limited number of tickets will be available at the door. Both previous "My Darlin' New Orleans" evenings sold out. Sweet Home New Orleans concentrates on the business side of the sustainability struggle for musicians, second-line organizations and Mardi Gras Indians. It aims "to make people a little more savvy about what they need to do to promote their musical careers, and tries to erase some of the digital divide, which is really an issue for our constituents," said Sue Mobley, executive director. Mobley said one of the organization's projects is working with musician Stafford Agee -- who plays the notes that emerge from Antoine Batiste's trombone on "Treme" -- to set up a horn-repair business in New Orleans. "Which is something we really need here," Mobley said. "It would be tremendous for the brass bands. We're such a bigger brass town than anywhere." Just as Sweet Home New Orleans helps musicians and others deal with fiscal-health issues, the New Orleans Musicians Clinic attends to their corporeal welfare, funding dental, hearing, diabetes and podiatric care, among many health-care needs. Foot care might seem minor, but in the community the clinic serves, it's not. "When you look at Mardi Gras Indians and second-liners and the brass bands, you realize how many of them suffer from diabetes, (and you see) how vital it is that they have their legs," said Bethany Bultman, clinic founder and president. For diabetic musicians who travel, the clinic arranges contacts and care in other cities when needed. "So when our patients leave New Orleans on gigs out of town or even out of the country, we have a broad network of doctors that we can access for our patients," Bultman said. "We try to be a member of the band." The Roots of Music, co-founded by drummer Derrick Tabb, is the pipeline for New Orleans' music of the future. The after-school music program for local kids also provides academic tutoring, a hot meal and transportation, no small job considering that some 70 percent of the band's members don't have family vehicles. Some of "My Darlin' New Orleans" benefit money may help fund one upcoming super-sized road trip: The Roots of Music Crusaders have been invited to march in the 2013 Rose Bowl Parade. "It's awesome," said Allison Reinhardt, executive director and co-founder. "It really is a great honor, but it's a steep cost." Which goes atop year-round operating costs. "All of our kids are low-income," Reinhardt said. "Our program is built to really accommodate children who don't have the resources for private academic tutoring or private music lessons. Even group lessons are just so expensive." The Crusaders made a memorable entrance at last year's "My Darlin' New Orleans" benefit, and are slated for an appearance again this year. "I've got to tell you, the people at HBO have been so amazing to us by putting the spotlight on our children," Reinhardt said. "We've gotten support from them individually. David Simon has been really great to us." Simon, with "Treme" co-creator Eric Overmyer, will be there Saturday night. Series actors Wendell Pierce, Clarke Peters, Melissa Leo, Lucia Micarelli and Michiel Huisman and new cast member Chris Coy are among those expected to attend. Irma Thomas headlines the music lineup. Food will be prepared by local super-chefs Susan Spicer, Tory McPhail and Alon Shaya. Auction items will include a signed Drew Brees jersey, a chance to appear on "Treme" during its third season (currently filming around town), a 1970 Jazz Fest poster that until recently hung in Preservation Hall and a Hammond B3 organ signed by Dr. John, Art Neville, Gregg Allman and JoJo Hermann of Widespread Panic. This "Treme" effect will be measurable. The organizations that will benefit from funds raised have seen it on the streets, too. No question, interest in Mardi Gras Indians, both locally and from visitors, appears to be much higher than it was before the series made one of its characters a gang chief. Sweet Home New Orleans' Mobley also believes the series has made a difference inside the communities from which future Indians will come. "It's sort of a fascinating case, because it's such a private culture," Mobley said. "I think there's some sense of conflict about being thrown into the limelight, but I also think that people are valuing or re-evaluating how they're seen. "I think that it has helped interest more people who could be part of the culture in becoming part of it. I think it's interested more people who are outsiders to learn more about it, to be engaged with it. "Super Sunday this year was the biggest crowd I've seen, ever." INFOBOX: My Darlin' New Orleans What: A fundraiser put on by HBO and the 'Treme' cast and crew to benefit organizations that serve New Orleans artists and cultural groups, including music from Irma Thomas, Little Freddie King, Meschiya Lake and the Little Big Horns; food from chefs Susan Spicer, Tory McPhail and Alon Shaya; and an auction. The event is in its third year. When: Saturday, 7-11 p.m. Where: Generations Hall, 310 Andrew Higgins Drive. Tickets: $150, mydarlinneworleans.eventbrite.com, through today. A limited number will be available at the door.

DOC.TI: 'Abbott needs personal politics lesson'
DOC.TEXT: OPPOSITION Leader Tony Abbott has again shown he needs a lesson in "personal politics 101" after making inappropriate remarks for a second time in a week, Attorney-General Nicola Roxon says. Mr Abbott said he regretted a remark he made in reference to Prime Minister Julia Gillard's wardrobe and appearance. Feminist Germaine Greer started the furore after she told an ABC TV panel that Ms Gillard wore unflattering jackets and had a "big arse". A woman speaking to Mr Abbott at a community forum in Victoria yesterday raised the subject again saying: "Get some of those jackets off her" and he replied: "I know, I know, I know. Germaine Greer was right on that subject." Mr Abbott said he regretted the remark when quizzed on the Channel 9 today. "It was an off-the-cuff remark responding to an observation of a member of the public and I shouldn't have said it and I regret it," he said. The latest verbal gaffe came just a week after Mr Abbott apologised in parliament for inappropriately saying Ms Gillard and the leader of the House of Representatives, Anthony Albanese, were "walking around with targets on their foreheads". Ms Roxon reminded reporters on Friday that Mr Abbott had abused Bernie Banton when he was dying from asbestos-induced fibrosis, and had "happily" swore at her (Ms Roxon) after a debate at the National Press Club. "This is Mr Abbott losing control and perhaps being under more pressure than he has been under in a while," she said. "But I also think this is Mr Abbott who needs a lesson on personal politics 101 which is, if your wife or girlfriend says, 'Does my bum look big in this?' you say, 'No' and get on with it." She didn't think it was appropriate for anyone to comment on the prime minister's clothing, including Ms Greer. "Germaine Greer really didn't do herself proud in making those comments," she said. Workplace Relations Minister Bill Shorten agreed, saying it was a case of an iconic feminist having a crack at another successful woman. "I wouldn't have said what Tony Abbott said, it was just ridiculous," Mr Shorten told Channel 7. Opposition treasury spokesman Joe Hockey told the same program it was a "no-go area" for any male to talk about female clothing. But he told Fairfax radio that the way one dresses and presents themselves does matter because it forms part of the judgment made of an individual. "For example, I can say to you, with absolute confidence, that you're unlikely to see me in Speedos," he said. But he said both Ms Gillard and Treasurer Wayne Swan had said some "nasty things" about him in the past. "For me it's water off a duck's back. It's no revelation that I'm a fully sized guy," he said. "Frankly when you pass comment about someone's weight or something like that I think it says more about you than it does about them."

DOC.TI: the lowdown; How lifestyle changes and supplements can improve blood pressure
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to preventing or treating high blood pressure, most of my clients prefer to try nonpharmaceutical therapies first, if possible. And for those who are already taking blood-pressure medications, making lifestyle changes may allow them to decrease or even discontinue the drugs. Last week, I covered the ins and outs of low-sodium diets, but nutritional strategies to manage blood pressure go far beyond simply limiting salt intake. Modifying lifestyle factors like diet and exercise, along with incorporating nutritional supplements, can make a significant impact. Priority No. 1: Lose weight. If you're heavy, shedding just 10 pounds can lower blood pressure enough to make it possible to reduce dosages of blood pressure medication. Exercise also plays a key role in achieving healthy blood-pressure levels. Not only can it help with weight loss, but physical activity also provides a natural diuretic effect through sweating, says Dr. Carl Lavie, medical director of cardiac rehabilitation and prevention at the John Ochsner Heart and Vascular Institute. "Exercise alone can lower blood pressure, independently of the impact that it has on body weight," says Lavie, who recommends 30 to 45 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity (e.g. brisk walk, jog or bike ride) most days of the week. Weight loss and exercise have been shown to reduce blood pressure, and the reduction is even more pronounced when combined with a lower-sodium diet that's rich in fruits, vegetables, low-fat dairy and whole grains. Alcohol influences blood pressure as well. Consuming more than three drinks per day is linked to a higher incidence of high blood pressure, and reducing alcohol intake seems to lower it. Also keep in mind that moderate alcohol consumption (defined as not more than one drink a day for women; two for men) also has a protective effect, decreasing our risk of cardiovascular disease as well as type 2 diabetes. In addition to weight loss, exercise, and a nutrient-dense diet, six key nutrients have been identified as key factors in lowering blood pressure: Potassium: Supplementing with potassium has been shown to moderately reduce blood pressure, with the greatest benefit appearing to be for people with low potassium levels, high daily sodium intakes, and for African Americans. But don't rush out to buy over-the-counter potassium supplements. The bad news is that a typical dose of potassium used in studies is about 1870 to 3500 mg daily, but you won't find more than 99 mg of potassium in an over-the-counter supplement. "The FDA placed this limit on potassium in dietary supplements years ago," says Sal Scaccia, Pharm.D., pharmacist and owner of Total Life Care Pharmacy in Harvey. "Too much potassium can be dangerous, potentially leading to heart issues such as heart attack if levels get too high, so it's important for patients to have their blood levels monitored by a physician if they're taking large doses of potassium. Prescription dosages of potassium are most commonly 750 mg and 1500 mg, much higher than in over-the-counter preparations," Scaccia says. The good news is that increasing the potassium in your diet seems to have a benefit similar to that of high-dose supplementation, and it's easier than you might think. Bananas tend to get the most press when it comes to potassium-rich foods, with a medium-sized banana providing about 422 mg. Yet a cup of red beans packs in more than 700 mg of potassium, a cup of cooked mushrooms has just over 550 mg, and a cup of milk contains about 450 mg. The potassium content of coconut water ranges from 290 to 550 mg per cup, and a 6-ounce carton of low-fat plain Greek yogurt provides 250 mg. Calcium: Supplementing with 1000 to 1500 mg calcium daily has been linked to a slight drop in blood pressure, with the benefits appearing to be more significant in people with a low dietary intake of calcium. And women 45 and older who have a higher intake of calcium (from both diet and supplements) seem to have a lower risk of developing hypertension compared to women with a lower calcium intake. It's possible to get this level of calcium through diet alone (yogurt, milk, calcium-fortified milk alternatives, cheese, fortified cereals and leafy greens can easily add up to 1500 mg, and many of these foods have the added benefit of being rich in potassium, as well), or through a combination of diet and supplementation. Fish oil: Supplementing with fish oil has been shown to modestly reduce blood pressure in patients with mild hypertension, with studies using either 4 grams of fish oil, or fish oil supplements that provide about 2 grams of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and 1.4 grams of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) daily. It's almost impossible to get these levels from diet alone. Soy protein: A daily dose of 40 grams of soy protein appears to cause a significant drop in blood pressure. This level of soy protein is typically accomplished by using a protein powder, although it can also be achieved with soy products like soy milk, tofu and edamame. High doses of soy aren't recommended for women with a personal or family history of hormone receptive positive breast cancer, however, because of the estrogen-like effects of soy's isoflavones. Chocolate: Cocoa is one of the top food sources of flavonoids, which are antioxidant-rich plant-based compounds. Consuming 400 to 500 mg daily of cocoa flavonoids has been shown to significantly lower blood pressure -- great news, except for the fact that this translates to about 3.5 ounces (and 500-plus calories) of chocolate daily, which unfortunately is not recommended for the majority of us. Better bets: Flavonol-enhanced cocoa, like CocoaVia (each 30-calorie stick pack provides 350 mg of cocoa flavonols to stir into coffee, milk, or protein shakes) or CocoaWell capsules with 450 mg of flavonols per serving. Coenzyme Q10: Coenzyme Q10 is a vitamin-like compound present in virtually all of our cells. Supplementing with Q10 (100 to 200 mg divided into two to three doses) has been shown to significantly lower blood pressure; in some cases enough to warrant the reduction or discontinuation of blood-pressure medications. Unlike the previously mentioned nutrients, CoQ10 is only found in very small quantities in food, so supplementation is needed to achieve these high levels. Check with your physician and pharmacist before beginning a supplement regime, particularly if you're taking medications, to ensure that there are no adverse effects. Don't change medication dosages without consulting your doctor. It's important to work with your health-care team to find the best combination of diet, exercise, supplements and medication that works for you.

DOC.TI: Record kidney cancer toll because of obesity
DOC.TEXT: BRITAIN'S obesity crisis has driven levels of kidney cancer to a record high, new figures show. The number of cases diagnosed each year in Britain has soared to just over 9,000 for the first time. This represents a huge increase of 135 per cent over the past 35 years, the figures from Cancer Research UK reveal. Experts believe obesity is fuelling the crisis. Being dangerously overweight can increase the risk of developing kidney cancer by 70 per cent. In 1975 there were 3,000 cases and it was the 14th most common cancer in Britain. But the numbers have been steadily rising ever since. The latest figures make it now the country's eighth most common cancer. Professor Tim Eisen, based at Cambridge University, said: "Over the last 10 years, Cancer Research UK has helped to develop new drugs which destroy the blood supply to the kidney cancers. "These drugs control the disease in most patients but do not cure it. "It is best to prevent the problem in the first place. Maintaining a healthy weight and not smoking are the best ways of doing that. The other important point is to see your doctor if you have noticed blood in your urine as this can be an early sign of something wrong. "If the kidney cancer is caught early, it can often be cured by surgery." Some of the increase is believed to be due to more widespread use of imaging techniques which help diagnose more kidney tumours. But evidence from other studies shows there has also been a rise in the number of advanced kidney cancer cases detected - suggesting other factors are also in play. Smoking After smoking, obesity is one of the main risk factors. Cancer Research UK figures estimate that a quarter of cases in men and 22 per cent in women are linked to being overweight. Smoking and obesity together are estimated to account for 42 per cent of all UK kidney cancer cases. Overweight people produce higher levels of certain hormones than those of a healthy size and this can contribute to an increased risk of several types of cancer including kidney. types of cancer including kidney. Whereas smoking rates are falling, obesity is on the rise. Whereas smoking rates are falling, BBC newscaster Nicholas Owen, 65, a kidney cancer survivor, said: "It's worrying to see the number of cases rise. It is so important for people to go to their doctor if they experience any symptoms like blood in urine. "The chances are it won't be cancer but if it is, spotting it early means that treatment is often easier and many "The chances are it won't be cancer but if it is, spotting it early means that treatment is often easier and many more people survive." Obesity is also linked to cancer of the breast, bowel, oesophagus, pan-Obesity is also linked to cancer of the breast, bowel, oesophagus, pancreas, womb and gallbladder.
