DOC.TI: Your child's milk tooth can save her life
DOC.TEXT: New Delhi, March 30 (IANS) Is your child about to lose her milk tooth? Instead of throwing it away, you can now opt to use it to harvest stem cells in a dental stem cell bank for future use in the face of serious ailments. Now that's a tooth fairy story coming to life. Still relatively new in India, dental stem cell banking is fast gaining popularity as a more viable option over umbilical cord blood banking. Stem cell therapy involves a kind of intervention strategy in which healthy, new cells are introduced into a damaged tissue to treat a disease or an injury. "The umbilical cord is a good source for blood-related cells, or hemaotopoietic cells, which can be used for blood-related diseases, like leukaemia (blood cancer). Having said that, blood-related disorders constitute only four percent of all diseases," Shailesh Gadre, founder and managing director of the company Stemade Biotech, told IANS. "For the rest of the 96 percent tissue-related diseases, the tooth is a good source of mesenchymal (tissue-related) stem cells. These cells have potential application in all other tissues of the body, for instance, the brain, in case of diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's; the eye (corneal reconstruction), liver (cirrhosis), pancreas (diabetes), bone (fractures, reconstruction), skin and the like," he said. Mesenchymal cells can also be used to regenerate cardiac cells. Dental stem cell banking also has an advantage when it comes to the process of obtaining stem cells. "Obtaining stem cells from the tooth is a non-invasive procedure that requires no surgery, with little or no pain. A child, in the age group of 5-12, is any way going to lose his milk tooth. So when it's a little shaky, it can be collected with hardly any discomfort," Savita Menon, a pedodontist, said. "Moreover, in a number of cases, when an adolescent needs braces, the doctor recommends that his pre-molars be removed. These can also be used as a source for stem cells. And over and above that, an adult's wisdom tooth can also be used for the same purpose," Gadre added. Therefore, unlike umbilical cord blood banking which gives one just one chance - during birth - the window of opportunity in dental stem cell banking is much bigger. "Of course, age is still a big factor," added Menon. "A child's milk tooth has more potency than a wisdom tooth. The ability of a young one's cells to multiply is twice as higher as anyone else." Pankaj Kala is one of those who opted for dental stem cell banking for his child. "I lost my mother to cardiac arrest when she was just 45. She was also a diabetic. After that I decided that I will do everything possible to protect my family from harm. I missed the opportunity of umbilical cord blood banking in the case of my daughter when she was born; so when she was six, we went for dental stem cell banking," Kala, who is in the jewellery business in Mumbai, told IANS. "It's been two years now and I have decided to go for the procedure for the second child too. Even my wife will go for stem cell banking using her wisdom tooth. In my case, however, it will be difficult since I had gone for root canal treatment in my wisdom tooth and therefore it's not healthy," he added. Anish Jain, another parent who has got his son's milk tooth extracted for stem cell banking, said: "I know stem cell therapy is a relatively new field, but I didn't want to have regrets later about not doing anything that could help my child if he suffers from any ailment." As of now, dental stem cell banking in India is offered by a select few companies, like Stemade and Store Your Cells. The procedure and then preservation of the stem cells can cost around Rs.100,000 for a period of 21 years. "Around 20 percent of those who have come to us for dental stem cell banking are doctors," said Gadre, who added they collect 60-70 samples every month. There are however sceptics. "Research is still on in stem cell therapy; so to tell people that harvesting your stem cells can save you from any serious disease is still a premature statement," said a doctor. DOC.TI: Johnson Controls Pricol Private Limited will be operating from Pune / Johnson Controls and Pricol establish joint venture for Indian automotive market
DOC.TEXT: Pune, India (ots) - Johnson Controls, a global leader in automotive seating, overhead systems, door and instrument panels, and interior electronics, has formed a joint venture with Pricol Limited, a leading supplier of automotive instrument clusters in India. The 50/50 joint venture will be called Johnson Controls Pricol Private Limited. Pricol's instrument cluster manufacturing plant in Pune will become the joint venture's primary location. It will develop and manufacture instrument clusters, displays and body electronics for both automakers and motorcycle manufacturers that operate businesses in India, by leveraging Johnson Controls' industry-leading Human Machine Interaction design and implementation expertise as well as product capabilities. "This new partnership combines the expertise and capabilities of Johnson Controls and Pricol to create a unique value proposition for our customers and differentiation in the industry," said Jeff DeBest, group vice president and general manager, electronics for Johnson Controls Automotive Experience. With Pricol's cost-effective innovation capabilities and strong customer relationships in the local market, Johnson Controls will realize growth potential in India. It also will serve global customers cost effectively. "Johnson Controls brings their world-class product development capabilities, global purchasing relationships and access to global customer relationships to this joint venture, which will help Pricol to strengthen our leading market position in India," said Vijay Mohan, chairman, Pricol. "Pricol's existing instrument cluster offerings and customer base for motorcycle makers will allow us to enter a new market segment," added DeBest. This new joint venture also will become Johnson Controls' global center of expertise for this product. About Johnson Controls: Johnson Controls is a global diversified technology and industrial leader serving customers in more than 150 countries. Our 162,000 employees create quality products, services and solutions to optimize energy and operational efficiencies of buildings; lead-acid automotive batteries and advanced batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles; and interior systems for automobiles. Our commitment to sustainability dates back to our roots in 1885, with the invention of the first electric room thermostat. Through our growth strategies and by increasing market share we are committed to delivering value to shareholders and making our customers successful. About Johnson Controls Automotive Experience: Johnson Controls is a global leader in automotive seating, overhead systems, door and instrument panels, and interior electronics. We support all major automakers in the differentiation of their vehicles through our products, technologies and advanced manufacturing capabilities. With 240 locations worldwide, we are where our customers need us to be. Consumers have enjoyed the comfort and style of our products, from single components to complete interiors. With our global capability we supply approximately 50 million cars per year. About Pricol: Pricol, which started its operations 35 years ago, is a well-known name in the Indian automotive component sector. Over the last 25 years, Pricol has been a leading supplier of automotive instrument clusters for two wheelers, cars, trucks and tractors in India. The company supports automakers and after-market customers across Europe, America, Middle East and Australasia and supplies instruments and other products including sensors, oil pumps, chain tensioners, fleet management solution products. DOC.TI: ECOLOGICAL TIERING AND THE EVOLUTION OF A STEM: THE OLDEST STEMMED FROND FROM THE EDIACARAN OF NEWFOUNDLAND, CANADA
DOC.TEXT: ABSTRACT- The ecological segregation of large, multicellular eukaryotes in the Ediacaran in response to competitive feeding results in the evolution of novel morphological adaptations such as sturdy stems to elevate above lower-tier feeding guilds. Culmofrons plumosa n. gen. n. sp. lived attached to the ocean floor and probably fed osmotrophically from dissolved organic nutrients in the water column. Competition for nutrients with specialized lower-tiered organisms resulted in the evolution of a specialized non-feeding structure, drastically expanding the functional morphospace available to Ediacaran rangeomorphs. The first appearance of a cylindrical macroscopic stem in C. plumosa in the Briscal Formation of the Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve marks a significant departure from the modular repetitive branching typical of the Rangeomorpha, and exemplifies the importance of nutrient acquisition in early ecosystem engineering. INTRODUCTION THE EDIACARA biota consist of a distinctive group of large (centimeter to meter scale), soft-bodied, and morphologically-complex organisms that span the latter part (579542 Ma) of the Ediacaran Period (Knoll et al., 2006). The relationships amongst the Ediacara biota are controversial, but likely consist of several différent clades (Xiao and Laflamme, 2009; Narbonne, 2011; Erwin et al., 2011), including stem/crown group animals (Gehling, 1991; Gehling and Rigby, 1996; Fedonkin and Waggoner, 1997; Sperling and Vinther, 2010) and several extinct clades of large, multicellular organisms, including the Erniettomorpha (Xiao and Laflamme, 2009) and the Rangeomorpha (Jenkins, 1985; Narbonne, 2004; Narbonne et al., 2009) that may be basal to metazoans. Rangeomorphs are modular organisms constructed from centimeter-scale elements (termed frondlets by Narbonne, 2004) consisting of at least three orders of selfrepeating or "fractal" (cf. Seilacher, 1992) branching. These frondlets are assembled like building blocks into larger constructions which can deviate from the self-repeating branching pattern to build complex fronds like Avalofr actus Narbonne, Laflamme, Greentree, and Trusler 2009, cabbageshaped Bradgatia Boynton and Ford 1995, spindle-shaped Fractofusus Gehling and Narbonne 2007, or even fence-like Pectinifrons Bamforth, Narbonne, and Anderson 2008 (Narbonne, 2004; Laflamme and Narbonne, 2008a). Rangeomorphs constituted more than 75% of all the megascopic organisms and filled most of the ecological roles in the Mistaken Point ecosystem (Clapham, et al., 2003; Bottjer and Clapham, 2006). Rangeomorphs have been assigned to many different groups. Originally, they were considered primitive ctenophores (Gurich, 1930, 1933; see also Dzik, 2002) or cnidarians (Misra, 1969; Glaessner, 1979; Jenkins, 1985; Runnegar and Fedonkin, 1992; Boynton and Ford, 1995) but were later found to have no morphological features characteristic of any living clade of animal (Pflug, 1972; Seilacher, 1992; Narbonne, 2004; Brasier and Antcliffe, 2004; Grazhdankin and Seilacher, 2005; Gehling and Narbonne, 2007; Sperling et al., 2007; Laflamme and Narbonne, 2008a, 2008b; Narbonne et al., 2009). Brasier and Antcliffe (2004) proposed that several Rangeomorpha taxa such as Bradgatia and Fractofusus could represent different stages of a Charnia Ford 1958 growth cycle but this has not been supported by subsequent character-based and morphometric work by Brasier and Antcliffe (2009) and Narbonne et al. (2009), which instead suggests a phylogenetic relationship between the morpho-taxa seen worldwide. Sperling et al. (2007) noted the absence of metazoan characters such as a water vascular system and suggested that rangeomorphs may represent stem-group opisthokonts (superkingdom that includes the animals and fungi). Regardless of their placement on the Tree of Life, it remains that the fractal branching frondlet is unique to the Rangeomorpha and unknown from any crown Metazoa (Narbonne, 2004; Xiao and Laflamme, 2009; Erwin et al., 2011), and likely represents an effective means of increasing the surface area to volume ratio in order to directly absorb dissolved organic matter (DOM) from the water column (osmotrophy; Sperling et al, 2007; Laflamme et al., 2009; Sperling et al., 2011). Rangeomorphs are entirely restricted to the Ediacaran, going extinct prior to the Great Cambrian Radiation (Narbonne, 2005). Rangeomorphs are a global group, known from the Flinders Ranges in South Australia, the White Sea region of Russia, Namibia in southern Africa, the Rocky Mountains in SW Canada, and the Avalon Zone of Newfoundland and England (Narbonne et al., 2009; Wilby et al., 2011). The Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve, outcropping all along the southeastern coast of the Avalon Peninsula of Newfoundland, is overwhelmingly dominated, in terms of diversity, disparity, and abundance, by rangeomorphs (Clapham et al., 2003; Bottjer and Clapham, 2006). Mistaken Point consists of a deep-ocean slope assemblage dominated by fine-grained turbidites (Wood et al., 2003). The fossils are exposed on dozens of large bedding surfaces throughout the ecological reserve. These bedding planes were formed due to the recessive nature of overlying centimeter- to meter-thick volcanic ash beds, which blanketed, smothered and felled the local Ediacaran populations and allowed for their preservation as in situ fossil communities. In addition to facilitating the casting and molding of these soft-bodied organisms, the volcanic ash yields zircons which have allowed for precise dating of the assemblages (Dunning in Benus, 1988; Bowring et al., 2003; van Kronendonk et al., 2008), implying that Mistaken Point represents the oldest assemblage of Ediacaratype fossils known anywhere (Narbonne and Gehling, 2003). Several studies have demonstrated a strong ecological signal at Mistaken Point, presumably in response to local competition for dissolved organic matter (Laflamme and Narbonne, 2008b), resulting in striking vertical subdivision of the water column into distinct tiers (Clapham and Narbonne, 2002), and a likely successional trend as communities became more complex (Clapham et al., 2003). The late succession community at Gull Rock Cove (or "Lower Mistaken Point"; Wood et al., 2003; Clapham et al., 2003) consists almost entirely of middle to upper-tier Ediacaran fronds such as Charniodiscus spinosus Laflamme, Narbonne, and Anderson 2004, Trepassia (Charnia) wardae Narbonne and Gehling 2003, and the meterlong Frondophyllas grandis Bamforth and Narbonne 2009. Here we describe the rangeomorph frond Culmofrons plumosa n. gen. n. sp. from the Briscal and Mistaken Point formations of the Avalon Peninsula in Newfoundland, Canada. Culmofrons marks a fundamental evolutionary step in rangeomorph construction, the first appearance of a prominent sturdy stem which elevated the feeding structure higher into the water column. This fundamental shift in rangeomorph morphospace would have provided a competitive advantage over lower-tiered specialists like Fractofusus, effectively limiting competition for nutrients by occupying a previously unoccupied niche, and represents a significant development in the evolution of tiered suspension-feeding communities. GEOLOGIC AND STRATIGRAPHIC SETTING Culmofrons plumosa has been reported from two horizons in the Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve (Fig. 1; "Charnia" or "Charnia B" in Clapham and Narbonne, 2002; Clapham et al., 2003). The oldest specimens are from the Bristy Cove section in the Briscal Formation (locality BC of Clapham et al., 2003), while the greatest numbers of specimens are from a surface at Gull Rock Cove at the base of the Mistaken Point Formation (locality LMP of Clapham et al., 2003). The Bristy Cove and Gull Rock Cove sections are temporally restricted between ash beds in the Drook Formation dated at 578.8 ± 0.5 Ma (van Kronendonk et al., 2008) and an ash bed directly overlying the well-studied E-surface of the Mistaken Point Formation dated at 565 +±3Ma (Dunning in Benus, 1988). The Mistaken Point succession was deposited in a deepwater environment considerably below both storm wave-base and the base of the photic zone (Misra, 1971; Benus, 1988; Myrow, 1995; Narbonne et al., 2001, 2005; Wood et al., 2003). The Briscal Formation consists of thick bedded T^sub (A)B(C)DE^ turbidites composed of gray medium- to coarse-grained sandstones with rare greenish mudstones deposited in a deep-water axial setting. The volcanic ashes responsible for Conception-style fossil preservation (Narbonne, 2005) are sporadic and only a few millimetres thick, resulting in a unique taphonomic window in which the fossils are preserved as dark outlines scattered over the bedding surface and are only visible when wet (Narbonne et al., 2001, 2005, 2009). The overlying Mistaken Point Formation consists mainly of thin- to medium-bedded T^sub (C)DE^ turbidites deposited in a deep-water slope or toe-of-slope setting. The Bristy cove section is overwhelmingly dominated by the lower-tier benthic reclining Fractofusus andersoni, with a significant contribution to the overall diversity by "Charnia B" (of Clapham et al., 2003) which represents two distinct taxa: the stemless Beothukis Brasier and Antcliffe 2009 and a long-stemmed form herein referred to Culmofrons plumosa. At Gull Rock Cove, over three hundred fossil specimens, most of which are fronds, have been identified on the single surface. Culmofrons was again labeled as Charnia Type B by Clapham et al. (2003). In all cases, the fronds display a strongly preferred felling orientation towards the NE, which is interpreted as representing alignment by a contour-parallel current (Wood et al., 2003; Narbonne et al., 2005). TAPHONOMY Mistaken Point organisms lived on a muddy sea bottom below storm wave-base and the photic zone. Coatings of volcanic ash covered, smothered, and felled the epibenthic fronds, and their fossils are preserved on the top surfaces of the interturbidite beds immediately under a layer of volcanic ash (Seilacher, 1999; Conception-style preservation of Narbonne, 2005). Labile minerals within the ash allowed for rapid lithification, resulting in casts of either the top surface of the organism itself, or its post-felling impression left in the seafloor mud and microbial mats (Gehling and Narbonne, 2007). This model predicts that least resistant (more labile) tissues, such as frond petalodia and rangeomorph frondlets, left an imprint in the ocean bottom sediments prior to decomposition. Following being felled and buried by volcanic ash, which effectively sealed off oxygen to the organism-mat/sediment interface, the activities of sulfur reducing bacteria resulted in the precipitation of iron sulfide coatings around the decaying carcass, which rapidly lithified to produce morphologicallyfaithful casts of the external morphology of these organisms (i.e., "Death Masks" of Gehling, 1999). The decay of the most labile tissues allowed ash to fill the voids remaining after decomposition to produce negative epirelief impressions. On the other hand, tissues less prone to decomposition, such as holdfast discs and frond stems, were coated by a layer of ash which solidified prior to their decay. After they decomposed, ocean bottom mud was injected upwards into the void and molded by the hardened layer of ash, producing positive epirelief casts. Two large specimens of Culmofrons are well-preserved along the entire length of the specimens (Fig. 2), including evidence of fractal rangeomorph frondlets in several primary branches (arrows in Fig. 2.2, 2.3). However, in most specimens only the discs, stems, primary branches, and proximal portions of the secondary branches were preserved. Given the discrepancy between rare, exceptionally preserved specimens and more common, moderately to poorly preserved specimens, it is possible that the quality of preservation was directly linked to the speed at which the specimens were felled and covered with ash. This degradation of préservation distally in fronds has also been noted in Charniodiscus Ford 1958 and Charnia from the Mistaken Point Formation (Laflamme et al., 2004, 2007). MATERIALS AND METHOD Two specimens of Culmofrons from Bristy Cove were photographed and an additional nine specimens from Gull Rock Cove were photographed and a latex mold taken to allow for detailed investigations in the laboratory. Specimens varied in preservational quality and completeness, and include a presumed ontogenetic series allowing for inferences concerning the growth patterns of Culmofrons (Fig. 2). Due to legal restrictions on collecting fossils from the Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve, no specimens were collected. Pervasive tectonic shortening is prevalent throughout the Avalon Peninsula (Seilacher, 1992; Wood et al., 2003), resulting in a 15-40% shortening of fossil dimensions in the direction of cleavage. This is most evident when evaluating the length/width ratios of oval holdfasts in frond specimens such as Culmofrons, which are demonstrably circular in similar species from all other Ediacaran-aged deposits worldwide. Furthermore, the direction of the long axis in the deformed oval holdfasts is consistently oriented in the same direction for all specimens on the same surface, regardless of their taxonomic affinity, size, or location on the surface (Wood et al., 2003). In order to rectify for this deformation, specimens are photographically or mathematical restored to their original shape, a process termed retrodeformation (Wood et al., 2003). Considering that specimens of Culmofrons all possess a circular holdfast, retrodeformation can be applied to each individual specimen. All photographs and measurements presented here (Table 1) have been retrodeformed. SYSTEMATIC PALEONTOLOGY Group RANGEOMORPHA Pflug, 1972 Subgroup CHARNIDA Narbonne, Laflamme, Greentree, Trusler, 2009 Genus CULMOFRONS new genus LAFLAMME, NARBONNE, GREENTREE AND ANDERSON, 2007, fig. 6d-euro. Type species. - Culmofrons plumosa new species, by monotypy. Diagnosis. - As for species. Etymology. - From the Latin "culmus" meaning stem and "frons" meaning frond, in reference to the long stem of the frond. CULMOFRONS PLUMOSA new species Figure 2 Diagnosis. - Rangeomorph frond with a spatulate to ovate petaloid composed of few (less than five on each side) alternating primary branches forming a zigzagging central axis. Basal primary branches attach directly to a long cylindrical stem and circular unornamented holdfast. Primary branches composed of several (between 8 to 12) sub-rectangular to trapezoidal secondary modular units oriented perpendicularly to the primary branches. Secondary modular units composed of cm-scale rangeomorph frondlets. Description. - Culmofrons consists of a 3.00 to 23.57 cm long (mean=12.80 cm; n=7) and 2.15 to 9.00 cm wide (mean=5.40 cm; n=7) petaloid with a 2.00 to 14.4 cm long (mean=7.47 cm; n=ll) stem and a disc with a large surface expression ranging in diameter from 0.90 to 6.00 cm (mean= 3.71 cm; n=ll). All well-preserved petaloids are composed of 4 to 6 sigmoidal primary branches (Fig. 2) which alternately stem at acute angles from a central axis, resulting in a zigzagging midline. Primary branches decrease in size and become more acute distally (Fig. 2), with larger proximal branches diverging from a central axis at 19° to 35° while the typically smaller distal branches diverge at 1° to 6°. The sigmoidal shape of individual primary branches is presumed to be taphonomically controlled (see Laflamme et al., 2007), and results from both the overlapping of primary branches across the midline as branches alternate from side-to-side, and from the distal end of each branch tucking itself behind subsequent branches. The largest primary branches are divided into 8 to 12 visible plumose secondary rangeomorph branches (Fig. 2) which stem from a location on primary branches overlapped by the neighboring distal branch. Basal secondary modular units are almost perpendicular to the central axis of the primary branches, however this angle becomes more acute distally. Proximal primary branches typically display a higher number of visible secondary units (8-12) whereas distal branches display significantly fewer (1-3). Isolated tertiary rangeomorph branches are visible in well-preserved specimens and are housed within the sub-rectangular secondary modules. Discussion. - The petalodium of two well-preserved specimens of Culmofrons (Fig. 2.1, 2.2) are approximately the same length (20.43-23.57 cm) but differ relatively more in width (6.43-8.0 cm). Measurements of primary branch angles indicate that the width of the petalodium, as well as that of individual branches, is dependent on the degree at which the primary branches diverge from a central axis (Fig. 2). This suggests that primary branches were capable of considerable lateral motion and were only attached to the stalk at their bases. The extent of overlap with adjacent branches is dictated by the branching angles of the primary branches, and thus the sizes of the primary and secondary branches are strongly linked to their preservation. However, despite these differences in primary branching angle, no evidence for a second half to the primary branches is seen in any part of any specimen, and therefore it is highly unlikely that the primary branches were originally double-sided. There is a large difference in the number of secondary branches per primary branch, with the most basal primary branches typically displaying the highest number of secondary branches and the most distal primary branches typically displaying the fewest. This trend is likely a combination of both biological and taphonomic signals. Basal primary branches are larger and likely represent the first primary branches to be constructed. Basal primary branches also have larger secondary modular units, implying that the rangeomorph element grew mostly by inflation after the initial fractal branching, a trend previously identified by Gehling and Narbonne (2007) for Fractofusus. The most distal primary branches are significantly smaller, are more poorly preserved, and are affected by a greater amount of overlap with adjacent primary branches, which may also explain the fewer number of secondary modular units. Several small specimens (between 5.00 cm and 8.75 cm long) of Culmofrons occur on the Gull Rock and Bristy Cove surfaces (Fig. 2.5). Their diminutive size results in a poor preservation of the delicate petalodium, and as such they do not display the detail visible in larger specimens. It is possible to identify the alternating primary branching pattern and a few likely secondary modular units. These specimens also possess a high-relief basal disc and a relatively long cylindrical stem. Laflamme and Narbonne (2008a, 2008b) classified Ediacaran fronds into four distinct groups based on their branching architecture: Arborea-, Charnia-, Rangea-, and Swartpuntia-type branching, likely representing distinct taxonomic clades. Swartpuntia-type branching is unknown from the Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve and consists of unbranching cylindrical tubular units with no similarity to the fractal architecture of Culmofrons. The presence of secondary sub-rectangular modular units housing fractal rangeomorph frondlets in Culmofrons is different from Arborea-type branching of Charniodiscus. Furthermore, the significantly fewer number of primary branches in Culmofrons irrespective of size also consistently distinguishes it from Charniodiscus (Laflamme et al., 2004). Rangea- and Charnia-type branching is hypothesized to represent a major division within the higher-order Rangeomorpha (Fig. 3; Narbonne et al., 2009). Rangea-type branching is restricted to rangeomorph fronds in which the primary branches consist of true fractal elements with secondary branches occurring on both halves of a primary branch. As such, the primary branches are remarkably similar to the centimeter-scale rangeomorph frondlet with secondary branches occurring on both sides of each primary branch (="doublesided rangeomorphs" in Fig. 3). The secondary branches in Charnia-type branching are restricted to a single side of each primary branch (= "single-sided rangeomorphs" in Fig. 3). It has been proposed that the main distinction between singlesided primary branches and double-sided primary branches represents a fundamental shift in construction, with doublesided Rangea-type primary branching consisting of a higherorder of fractal branching whereas single-sided Charnia-type branching represents a departure from a fractal construction above the rangeomorph frondlet or secondary branch (Narbonne et al., 2009). The primary branches of Culmofrons are single-sided, with double-sided rangeomorph frondlets restricted to the secondary modular elements (Fig. 3). Furthermore, the sigmoidal primary branches alternate and cross-over the central midline to create a zigzagging central axis. These characteristics allow Culmofrons to be distinguished from Rangea Gürich 1930 and Avalofractus, which both display Rangea-type double-sided fractal primary branches, and suggest an affinity with the Charnida as defined by Narbonne et al., 2009. Although the primary branching structure in Culmofrons is similar to Charnia, Trepassia, and Beothukis, Culmofrons can consistently be distinguished from these forms in possessing a long cylindrical stem. Furthermore, unlike Charnia (Antcliffe and Brasier, 2007) and Trepassia (Narbonne et al., 2009), Culmofrons does not appear to add primary branches when constructing its petalodium, restricting its branch count to less than half a dozen (all well-preserved specimens have no more than four). It appears as though the primary branches, once acquired, increase in size through individual growth of the fractal modular units. The number of primary branches is also helpful in differentiating Culmofrons from Beothukis, which exhibits at least six primary branches, with several specimens possessing nine to ten primary branches. It is important to note that the overall shape of the Culmofrons frond is most similar to Avalofractus, due to the convergence in overall form in constructing a cylindrical stem to which an ovate petaloid is attached. It has been argued that overall frond shape, consisting of a holdfast, stem, and petaloid, is a convergent trend in several Ediacara taxa and results from a shared need to extract nutrients from the water-column (Narbonne and Laflamme, 2008a, 2008b). As such, we placed greater emphasis on frond architecture, which in Culmofrons highlights a Charnia-type branching structure most similar to Beothukis, Charnia, and Trepassia. Primocandelabrum Hofmann, O'Brien and King 2008 from the Bonavista Peninsula of Newfoundland is only partially preserved thus severely limiting the extent to which branching structure can be examined, however no rangeomorph elements are known in any specimens of Primocandelabrum (Hofmann et al., 2008). Furthermore, Primocandelabrum^ holdfast disc is characterized by distinct appendages that radiate from the holdfast producing a Hiemalora-like disc (see fig. 12 in Hofmann et al., 2008), which are distinctly lacking in Culmofrons. This distinction cannot be attributed to taphonomy since isolated Hiemalora discs have been reported from Gull Rock Cove (Narbonne et al., 2001; Hofmann et al., 2008). Occurrence and stratigraphie range. - Culmofrons occurs at two stratigraphie levels in the Mistaken Point Ecological Reserve (Fig. 1). The oldest specimens are known from the middle Briscal Formation at Bristy Cove, while younger specimens occur in the lower part of the Mistaken Point Formation at Gull Rock Cove (Fossil Surface F3 in Wood et al., 2003). Etymology. - Plumosa refers to the feather-like shape of the frond as well as the plumose nature of the rangeomorph branches within the petalodium. Holotype. - The ecological reserve status at Mistaken Point prevents any specimen collection, however previous studies (Hofmann et al., 2008; Brasier and Antcliffe, 2009; Bamforth and Narbonne, 2009) have designated a field holotype and a corresponding plaster or latex type reposited in a museum. Royal Ontario Museum Plastotype ROM 61522 (Fig. 2.2) from the Mistaken Point Formation at Gull Rock Cove in southeast Newfoundland has a 23.57 cm long and 8.0 cm wide petalodium, with a 10.0 cm long stem and a 5.0 cm diameter holdfast. Three-dimensional reconstruction. - The nature of Conception-style preservation is such that originally three-dimensional organisms are cast by beds of volcanic ash as twodimensional impressions on the top surfaces of bedding planes. As such, taphonomic clues in addition to direct morphological evidence must be incorporated into any threedimensional reconstructions (Laflamme et al., 2007; Narbonne et al., 2009). Characters preserved in positive epirelief, such as the cylindrical stems and circular holdfasts, suggest that these tissues were more resistant to decomposition (Seilacher, 1992, 1999; Narbonne, 2005). On the other hand, rangeomorph frondlets are preserved in negative epirelief, presumed to have been formed in response to the collapse/decomposition of the labile tissue, thus allowing the overlying ashbeds to infill the void (Narbonne, 2005; Gehling and Narbonne, 2007). In two dimensions the petalodium appears to be a single sheet-like structure but taphonomic features suggest otherwise. The difference in primary branching angle in specimens dictates the shape of the petalodium (Fig. 2). Petalodia of specimens with high primary branching angles appear streamlined and elongated whereas specimens with lower primary branching angles are distinctly wider. The variation in primary branching angle is apparent in all specimens studied. This implies that primary branches were strongly anchored at their proximal bases and only loosely attached (if at all) at their distal tips. This results in a high degree of lateral motility in the primary branches, varying degrees of primary branch overlap and bundling, and ultimately varying widths of the petalodium. The taphomorphology of the petalodium, or the apparent shape differences resulting from preservational variations, changes with differing amounts of overlap and is governed by primary branching angles. The primary branching angle also dictates the extent to which secondary branches are revealed in two dimensions and thus their apparent shape, a trend also evident in Charnia (Laflamme et al., 2007). TIERING AND THE CONSTRUCTION OF A STEM One of the most striking features of the Mistaken Point assemblage is the distinct tiering component resulting from direct competition between organisms for particulates or dissolved nutrients within the water column (Clapham and Narbonne, 2002). In the absence of prédation, ecological competition associated with nutrient sequestration led to distinct speciation events (Laflamme et al., 2004), expansion of functional morphospace (Laflamme and Narbonne, 2008b), and ultimately ecosystem complexity and succession (Clapham et al., 2003). Culmofrons is striking in representing the first rangeomorph frond with a prominent cylindrical stem, and its first appearance in conjunction with the first appearance of dedicated lower-tiered specialists like Fractofusus (Gehling and Narbonne, 2007) and Bradgatia (Flude and Narbonne, 2008) in the Briscal Formation suggests that direct competition for nutrients above the sediment-water interface started an ecological escalation leading to complex ecological tiering and communities strikingly similar to those exhibited by suspension feeders living on modern slopes (Clapham and Narbonne, 2002; Clapham et al., 2003). Prior to the advent of Culmofrons, Ediacaran fronds such as Charnia and Trepassia shared certain distinct features, including the continual addition of modular primary branches resulting in longer fronds which fed along the entire length of the petalodium (Antcliffe and Brasier, 2007; Laflamme et al., 2007; Narbonne et al., 2009). The distinct absence of a stem, coupled with the remarkable preservation of >2 meter long fronds beneath mm-thick layers of volcanic ash suggests that the fronds were lying perpendicular to the seafloor, only a few centimeters above the sediment-water interface. As the deepocean unidirectional currents transported dissolved organic nutrients along the entire length of the frond, the high surfacearea to volume ratio of the fractal rangeomorph elements would adsorb nutrients which diffused through the integument via osmosis. The fractal elements may also have caused minor disruptions in the laminar flow in the deep-water unidirectional currents, resulting in micro-vortices which aided in the transfer of nutrients across the boundary layer. This mode of life was ideal until the appearance of lower-tier specialist such as Fractofusus and Bradgatia in the Briscal Formation. These represent a fundamentally different construction that focused on building a fixed number of rangeomorph elements which inflated in size throughout ontogeny. Although inflating the fractal element naturally results in a lower surface area to volume ratio (Laflamme et al., 2009), the net increase in overall surface area, combined with a greater spacing between each fractal division throughout the rangeomorph element (e.g., exposing more surface area directly to the water column), results in an ideal construction for lower-tiered osmotrophs. It has also been suggested, based on detailed taphonomic studies of thousands of specimens at Mistaken Point, that Fractofusus may have had a petaloid sticking upwards into the water-column, resulting in a three-veined "" shape (Gehling and Narbonne, 2007). Culmofrons can be compared to Phanerozoic primary solitary tierers of Bottjer and Ausich (1986). All complete large specimens of Culmofrons occur in the 22-35 cm tier of Clapham and Narbonne (2002). The primary branches of Culmofrons are flexible and are only anchored to the central stalk and therefore not attached to one another, presumably allowing for water currents to flow through the individual branches. As is the case with Charniodiscus procerus Laflamme, Narbonne, and Anderson 2004, the long stem elevated the petalodium above competitive lower tiers (Laflamme et al., 2004), and as such did not require as large of a petalodium when compared to stemless forms which fed closer to the sediment-water interface and/or fed along the entire length of the organism. It is interesting to note that, unlike Charniodiscus, which has a worldwide distribution and dominates shallow-water assemblages, Culmofrons is restricted to deep-water assemblages. Similar trends in the distribution of Charnia were interpreted (Laflamme et al., 2007) as evidence that limited branch motility was necessary for effective feeding in shallow-water environments. Ecological succession has been proposed to explain the differences in tiering, disparity, and species abundances between distinct fossil horizons at Mistaken Point, with each individual bed providing a snapshot of different ecological stages of succession (Clapham et al., 2003). The Gull Rock Cove surface is typical of a late succession stage community with a lower diversity and evenness when compared to midsuccession communities, and where vertical partitioning of the water column is well-developed (Clapham et al., 2003). The surface is dominated by fronds and displays a tolerance model of succession where organisms adapted to higher resource levels are progressively replaced by those adapted to lower resource levels (Clapham et al., 2003). This suggests that Culmofrons was perhaps adapted to lower resource levels. CONCLUSIONS Culmofrons plumosa was the first Ediacaran frond to attach its petalodium to its holdfast using a long stem, and thus the first Ediacaran frond to extend into upper feeding tiers in the water column. The petalodium is divided into a few primary branches that alternate to form a zigzagging central midline. The petalodium of Culmofrons shares branching characteristics with organisms displaying Charnia-type branching consisting of secondary rangeomorph frondlets housed within semi-rectangular secondary modular elements occurring on one side of a primary branch. The primary branches in Culmofrons were flexible and were only anchored proximally to the stalk. Culmofrons lived epifaunally, attached to the ocean floor and diffusively fed from dissolved organic nutrients in the water column. Its long stem elevated its petalodium higher into the water column as a direct result of competition with specialized lower-tiered organisms. DOC.TI: Two business owners vie for RGC commission seat
DOC.TEXT: March 30--RIO GRANDE CITY -- Two local business owners say they can help move the city forward if they are elected to the city commission. Dave "Chachi" Jones, a private investigator who owns a bail bonds company, is running against Juan "Andy" Hernandez, a home healthcare nurse and business owner, for the Place 4 Rio Grande City Commission seat. That seat will be left vacant by Ruben D. Saenz, who is running to keep his appointed County Commission seat. City Commissioner Rey Ramirez is up for re-election, but no one filed to run against him. Jones is running on a slate with Mayor Ruben Villarreal with support from Ramirez. Hernandez is running independently. Jones, 42, has run for several other local elections, including county clerk, district clerk and city commission. Jones said he has gained experience from his losses. He also served as a Starr County Democratic Party precinct chair. He previously ran as an independent and said he appreciates the support he will receive from running on a slate. "Running independently in Starr County is a long shot. Been there, done that," he said, adding that running with a slate is going to "get me over that hurdle to finally be a public servant to the community." Hernandez, 30, has served as the president of the former Greater Rio Grande City Chamber of Commerce, as the vice president of the Rio Grande City Main Street Program and with other philanthropic organizations, but he has never run for office. He also owns a Star Communication store and Underground World Tattoo Studio. "I'm not for owing favors at the end of the day," he said of his decision to run independently. "I am something new. I am something fresh. I have a lot of ideas." Hernandez said he can use his experience in the medical and business fields to try to bring more medical facilities to the area as well as educate the public about common health problems, such as diabetes. He and Jones agree that they want to bring more business to the area. Jones, a father of two who owns Chachi's Bail Bonds, said he wants to bring more jobs to the area to retain talented youth. "I want to ...have our kids come back after college come back and establish themselves in Rio Grande City other than them leaving and having to find jobs somewhere else," he said. Hernandez said he thinks the city should try to bring more businesses up from Mexico. The two city commission seats will not be the only places on the May 12 ballot. Local business owner Arturo Lopez is challenging Villarreal for his mayoral seat. -- Gail Burkhardt covers Mission, western Hidalgo County, Starr County and general assignments for The Monitor. DOC.TI: Johnson Controls Pricol Private Limited Will be Operating From Pune
DOC.TEXT: PUNE, India, March 30, 2012 /PRNewswire/ -- Johnson Controls and Pricol Establish Joint Venture for Indian Automotive Market Johnson Controls, a global leader in automotive seating, overhead systems, door and instrument panels, and interior electronics, has formed a joint venture with Pricol Limited, a leading supplier of automotive instrument clusters in India. The 50/50 joint venture will be called Johnson Controls Pricol Private Limited. Pricol's instrument cluster manufacturing plant in Pune will become the joint venture's primary location. It will develop and manufacture instrument clusters, displays and body electronics for both automakers and motorcycle manufacturers that operate businesses in India, by leveraging Johnson Controls' industry-leading Human Machine Interaction design and implementation expertise as well as product capabilities. "This new partnership combines the expertise and capabilities of Johnson Controls and Pricol to create a unique value proposition for our customers and differentiation in the industry," said Jeff DeBest, group vice president and general manager, electronics for Johnson Controls Automotive Experience. With Pricol's cost-effective innovation capabilities and strong customer relationships in the local market, Johnson Controls will realize growth potential in India. It also will serve global customers cost effectively. "Johnson Controls brings their world-class product development capabilities, global purchasing relationships and access to global customer relationships to this joint venture, which will help Pricol to strengthen our leading market position in India," said Vijay Mohan, chairman, Pricol. "Pricol's existing instrument cluster offerings and customer base for motorcycle makers will allow us to enter a new market segment," added DeBest. This new joint venture also will become Johnson Controls' global center of expertise for this product. About Johnson Controls: Johnson Controls is a global diversified technology and industrial leader serving customers in more than 150 countries. Our 162,000 employees create quality products, services and solutions to optimize energy and operational efficiencies of buildings; lead-acid automotive batteries and advanced batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles; and interior systems for automobiles. Our commitment to sustainability dates back to our roots in 1885, with the invention of the first electric room thermostat. Through our growth strategies and by increasing market share we are committed to delivering value to shareholders and making our customers successful. About Johnson Controls Automotive Experience: Johnson Controls is a global leader in automotive seating, overhead systems, door and instrument panels, and interior electronics. We support all major automakers in the differentiation of their vehicles through our products, technologies and advanced manufacturing capabilities. With 240 locations worldwide, we are where our customers need us to be. Consumers have enjoyed the comfort and style of our products, from single components to complete interiors. With our global capability we supply approximately 50 million cars per year. About Pricol: Pricol, which started its operations 35 years ago, is a well-known name in the Indian automotive component sector. Over the last 25 years, Pricol has been a leading supplier of automotive instrument clusters for two wheelers, cars, trucks and tractors in India. The company supports automakers and after-market customers across Europe, America, Middle East and Australasia and supplies instruments and other products including sensors, oil pumps, chain tensioners, fleet management solution products. DOC.TI: PRESS DIGEST-New York Times business news - March 30
DOC.TEXT: March 30 (Reuters) - The following were the top stories on the New York Times business pages on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy. * A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former graduate student at a Chinese university - putting a face on the persistent espionage by Chinese hackers against foreign companies and groups. * At a time of plunging DVD sales and an up-and-down box office, Hollywood is doubling back on past hits in search of profits. Often the remakes feature familiar stars playing iconic roles, like Bruce Willis, 57, who is preparing for yet another "Die Hard" film, his fifth. * Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, the manufacturing giant Foxconn has pledged to sharply curtail working hours and significantly increase wages inside Chinese plants making electronic products for Apple and others. The move could improve working conditions across China. * Despite a tumultuous 2011, fees helped hedge fund managers at larger hedge firms make $14.4 billion. * Moody's Investors Service, one of the two big ratings agencies, has said it will decide in mid-May whether to lower its ratings for 17 global financial companies. Morgan Stanley , which was hit hard in the financial crisis, appears to be the most vulnerable. Moody's is threatening to cut the bank's ratings by three notches, to a level that would be well below the rating of a rival like JPMorgan Chase. * A plan to impose a tax on hot take-away food while lowering income taxes on millionaires brings back memories of other unpopular measures imposed by the government. * Jim Flaherty, the finance minister of Canada, pronounced a death sentence on the country's penny during his budget speech on Thursday. The government estimated that every penny costs it about 1.6 cents to produce. Eliminating the penny's production will reduce the government's costs by about 11 million Canadian dollars a year. * Representatives of advertising companies, Internet sites and technology companies told a House subcommittee on Thursday that they thought Internet privacy policies, including Do Not Track options, should be created through an "open and transparent" process, as two government agencies have recommended. * Two candidates from developing nations are challenging the American nominee, a move that reflects the fast-growing clout of emerging economies. For the first time, the World Bank is considering more than one candidate for its five-year presidency - a change that reflects the fast-growing clout of emerging economies, even as it raises questions over whether that change is coming quickly enough. * An advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration said obesity drugs should get extra testing to ensure against heart attacks and strokes.

DOC.TI: UPDATE 2-Roche to file T-DM1 breast cancer drug on good data
DOC.TEXT: * T-DM1 superior to Tykerb plus Xeloda in Phase III study * Filing planned for Europe and U.S. this year * T-DM1 delivers toxic payload with fewer side effects (Adds analyst comment, peak sales forecast) ZURICH, March 30 (Reuters) - Roche said patients with an aggressive type of breast cancer lived longer after taking its experimental "armed antibody" drug without the disease worsening than those on a mix of GlaxoSmithKline drug Tykerb and Roche's Xeloda. The positive results from the first Phase III trial of the medicine - dubbed T-DM1 - clears the way for it to be submitted to European and U.S. authorities for approval this year, boosting prospects for a key asset in the Swiss firm's pipeline. WestLB analyst Oliver Kaemmerer, who sees peak sales potential for T-DM1 of around 1 billion Swiss francs ($1.1 billion), said the latest news was clearly positive but it remained to be seen what the overall magnitude of the benefit was in the study. In a brief statement on Friday, Roche revealed only that patients on T-DM1 lived "significantly longer" without their disease progressing. Roche has been developing T-DM1 with ImmunoGen as a successor to its blockbuster Herceptin, which is expected to generate sales of around $6 billion this year. A key advantage of T-DM1 over Herceptin is the fact that it causes fewer adverse side effects like hair loss and low white blood cell counts. It combines trastuzumab, an antibody and the active ingredient in Herceptin, with the agent DM1 - a derivative of an extremely powerful type of chemotherapy called maytansine - which is carried directly into cells. As well as having fewer unpleasant side effects, Roche believes its new drug also offers greater convenience, since it is one drug and eliminates the need to administer chemotherapy. Analyst hopes for T-DM1 have been running high, following earlier good results in Phase II tests, and a filing of the product with regulators this year had been widely expected on the back of data from the so-called EMILIA clinical trial. Roche said the EMILIA progression-free survival data would be presented at an upcoming medical meeting, adding that final results for overall survival were not yet mature. Kaemmerer of WestLB believes the full set of results for progression-free survival are likely to be presented at the June 1-5 annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology, with overall survival results becoming available by 2014. Commercially, T-DM1 should help protect Roche's breast cancer franchise, since Herceptin could be exposed to so-called "biosimilar" generic competition in Europe from around 2015. It also keeps Roche in the breast cancer innovation race in the face of newer medicines that aim to rival Herceptin, like GSK's Tykerb. ($1 = 0.9073 Swiss francs) (Reporting By Katharina Bart and Ben Hirschler; Editing by Hans-Juergen Peters)

DOC.TI: John Elkington Drunks, lampposts and sustainability
DOC.TEXT: Remember the drunk stumbling around under the street lamp? He's lost his car keys. Asked if that's where he lost them, he replies no, he mislaid them in the dark - this is where the light is. Let's draw a lesson from this old tale, and look beyond existing areas of light into the darker areas from which a new world economic order is emerging. Enthusiasts for corporate rankings know the same names appear routinely at - or near - the top. So while I was pleased to see Denmark's Novo Nordisk head the Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations table - published by Canadian magazine Corporate Knights - it seemed another turn of an overly familiar wheel. Thankfully, the world's leading insulin supplier has moved well beyond its still rare incorporation of triple bottom-line principles (people, planet and profit) into its charter. But for less-known sustainability champions, look elsewhere. A report published for the 2012 World Economic Forum was subtitled The New Sustainability Champions. Prepared by BCG, it spotlights 16 companies in countries such as Brazil, Costa Rica, Egypt and Kenya. The conclusion? Such businesses "tend to grow faster and have higher-than-average margins for their industries". But how? By turning constraints into opportunities, embedding sustainability into their cultures, and actively shaping their business environments. Under the first heading, they confront natural resources constraints directly, educating customers on improving efficiency and providing ways for poorer people to access products and services. When it comes to embedding values, they define clear goals, galvanising the entire organisation; they integrate sustainability into their operations; and they engage their workforces. Finalty, they shape policies, standards and behaviours. China's Broad Group has developed a miniature device for measuring air pollution that fits inside a mobile phone. By putting air quality information into citizens' hands, they usefully amplify societal pressure for change. Copyright Institute of Directors Mar 2012

DOC.TI: Breakfast club; L.A. Unified is offering a morning meal in classrooms, not just cafeterias, to better ensure that students get something to eat
DOC.TEXT: Amayrany Reyes ignored the yogurt but gobbled up her strawberries and nibbled her blueberry muffin. Then the bright-eyed third-grader, sporting a pink bow in her long braid, delivered the verdict on breakfast in her Los Angeles classroom. "Everything is good," she said, adding that the food makes her feel more energetic. More than 200,000 students in 267 schools will enjoy such breakfast benefits in the next year under a major initiative announced Thursday by the Los Angeles Unified School District and the L.A. Fund for Public Education, a fundraising group. The "Food for Thought" program, which will take morning meals into the classroom rather than just the cafeteria, is aimed at boosting the share of students who eat school breakfast from 29% to 70%, according to David Binkle, the district's food services deputy director. Children from low-income families -- who make up about 80% of L.A. Unified students -- are less likely to eat breakfast, according to the California Food Policy Advocates. Some parents may not be able to afford the food; others may leave for work too early to make breakfast for their children. Betty Carrillo, an East L.A. mother, said she has to leave for work at 5:30 a.m. and is never certain whether her older son feeds her younger one a nutritious breakfast. Yet research has linked breakfast consumption to higher academic performance, fewer discipline problems, less obesity and reduced visits to school nurses for headaches and other ailments. "Our mothers were right: Breakfast really is the most important meal of the day," said Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa at the program's kick-off event at Figueroa Street Elementary School in South Los Angeles. Similar programs have been introduced in Chicago, Houston, San Diego, Detroit and Compton as a key strategy to feed breakfast to more children, especially those in poverty. At Figueroa Street, cameras clicked while Amayrany and two dozen classmates dug into their morning fare flanked by actress Sophia Vergara, L.A. Unified board President Monica Garcia and Supt. John Deasy. Sadale White, who comes to school early to help deliver the pre-packed breakfast kits and lay out paper trays and place mats, said his favorite treats are strawberries and other fresh fruits. The school has quadrupled breakfast consumption from a quarter of the students to nearly all of them since rolling out the pilot program in January. Principal Tanya Stokes-Mack said the benefits were immediately noticeable: fewer absences, tardies and visits to the school nurse. Although the school offered free- and reduced-price breakfasts before school, students who were late missed them and others preferred to spend the time playing rather than eating. "Now it's more of a classroom activity that students don't want to be left out of," Stokes-Mack said. "There's a lot of camaraderie eating with your teacher and classmates." In high schools and some middle schools, the district plans to set up kiosks around campus with breakfast kits that students can grab and take into class. L.A. Unified hopes eventually to expand the program to 676 campuses serving more than 500,000 students in three years. Such an expansion could bring in an estimated $23.5 million annually in federal school meal reimbursements, Binkle said. The program marks the first initiative by the L.A. Fund, launched last year by Deasy and philanthropist Megan Chernin to raise $200 million over five years for local public schools. The foundation is providing about $200,000 to help develop nutrition education, train teachers in ways to provide it during the 10- to 15-minute breakfast period and work with vendors to improve food quality. "It's healthy, it's good and it gives kids the boost they need in the morning," Chernin said. Nataly Escobar, 11, would agree. The classroom breakfasts are so good the fifth-grader said she gobbles them up even though she also eats eggs and toast at home before coming to school. "If you don't eat breakfast," she said, "you won't feel smart." -- teresa.watanabe@latimes.com

DOC.TI: Novo Nordisk/Nordea: Victoza kan forsinkes 2-3 år i fedme
DOC.TEXT: Novo Nordisks lancering af Victoza til fedmebehandling kan blive to til tre år forsinket. Det vurderer Nordea er den mulige konsekvens af, at et ekspertpanel under den amerikanske lægemiddelstyrelse, FDA, torsdag anbefalede at skærpe kravene til kommende vægttabsmidler, rapporterer Bloomberg News. Stort set den samme holding har Jyske Bank i følge bankens chefrådgiver Michael Lyngsø. FDA-eksperterne anbefalede med stemmerne 17-6 at gennemføre hjerte-kar-studier, selv hvis der ikke er synlige tegn på, at stoffet øger risikoen for hjerte-kar-sygdomme. Panelet anbefalede samtidig at inkludere endnu flere patienter i risikogruppen i studierne, det vil sige patienter, der lider af svær fedme og ældre og endnu sygere patienter, skriver Wall Street Journal. FDA følger normalt indstillingerne fra ekspertpanelerne, men har det endelige ord i forhold til at udvikle de nye retningslinjer for fedmemedicin. DOC.TEXT:
COMPANY ANNOUNCEMENT NO. 18/2012 30 MARCH 2012 To the shareholders of Royal Unibrew A/S CVR No 41956712 The Board of Directors of Royal Unibrew A/S hereby gives notice of the Annual General Meeting 2012 of the Company Monday 30 April 2012 at 4 pm at TOLDBODEN, Nordre Toldbod 24, DK-1259 Copenhagen K Agenda: 1. Report on the Companys activities during the year. 2. Presentation of the audited Annual Report for 2011, including auditors report for adoption and resolution to discharge the Board of Directors and the Executive Board from their ob-ligations in respect of the Annual Report. The Board of Directors proposes that the audited Annual Report for 2011 be adopted and that the Board of Directors and the Executive Board are discharged from their obligations in respect of the Annual Report. 3. Proposed distribution of profit for the year, including resolution on the amount of dividend. The Board of Directors proposes to pay out a dividend of DKK 190 million in total corresponding to DKK 17 per share of DKK 10. 4. Approval of remuneration of the Board of Directors for 2012. The Board of Directors proposes unchanged fees for 2012 based on a basic fee of DKK 250,000 multiplied by 2½ and 1¾ for the Chairman and Deputy Chairman, respectively. 5. Consideration of proposed resolutions submitted by the Board of Directors or shareholders. 5.1 Cancellation of treasury shares: The Board of Directors proposes that the share capital be reduced by a nominal amount of DKK 6,164,980 to a nominal amount of DKK 105,700,000 by cancelling 616,498 treasury shares of a nominal value of DKK 10 each, i.e. by distribution to shareholders in accordance with section 179 (1) (3) of the Danish Companies Act. The shares are acquired for a total amount of DKK 224,725,851 corresponding to an average price of DKK 364.52. 5.2 Authorisation for capital increase: It is proposed that the existing authorisation of the Board of Directors to increase the Companys share capital according to Article 7 (1) of the Articles of Association be extended until 30 April 2017 and that certain editorial changes be made to adapt the authorisation to the changed registration practice of the Danish Business Authority. Article 7 of the Articles of Association shall hereafter read as follows: Sub-Article 1 The Board of Directors shall be authorised to increase the Companys share capital by one or more issues of new shares, with the existing shareholders having a pre-emptive right to subscribe for the new shares, up to a total nominal amount of DKK 11,000,000, subject, however, to Sub-Article 3 hereof. The authorisation shall remain in force up to and including 30 April 2017. Sub-Article 2 The Board of Directors shall be authorised to increase the Companys share capital by one or more issues of new shares, without the existing shareholders having a pre-emptive right to subscribe for the new shares, up to a total nominal amount of DKK 11,000,000, subject, however, to Sub-Article 3 hereof. The increase may be realised without the existing shareholders having a pre-emptive right to subscribe for the new shares if carried out at market price or as consideration for the Companys acquisition of an existing business or specific capital assets at a value corresponding to the value of the shares issued hereby. The authorisation shall remain in force up to and including 30 April 2017. Sub-Article 3 

The Board of Directors authorisation pursuant to

Sub-Articles 1 and 2 hereof may be exercised to                issue new shares

DOC.TI: JOHNSON CONTROLS PRICOL PRIVATE LIMITED WILL BE OPERATING FROM PUNE
DOC.TEXT: PUNE, India, March 30, 2012 /PRNewswire/ -- Johnson Controls and Pricol Establish Joint Venture for Indian Automotive Market Johnson Controls, a global leader in automotive seating, overhead systems, door and instrument panels, and interior electronics, has formed a joint venture with Pricol Limited, a leading supplier of automotive instrument clusters in India. The 50/50 joint venture will be called Johnson Controls Pricol Private Limited. Pricol's instrument cluster manufacturing plant in Pune will become the joint venture's primary location. It will develop and manufacture instrument clusters, displays and body electronics for both automakers and motorcycle manufacturers that operate businesses in India, by leveraging Johnson Controls' industry-leading Human Machine Interaction design and implementation expertise as well as product capabilities. "This new partnership combines the expertise and capabilities of Johnson Controls and Pricol to create a unique value proposition for our customers and differentiation in the industry," said Jeff DeBest, group vice president and general manager, electronics for Johnson Controls Automotive Experience. With Pricol's cost-effective innovation capabilities and strong customer relationships in the local market, Johnson Controls will realize growth potential in India. It also will serve global customers cost effectively. "Johnson Controls brings their world-class product development capabilities, global purchasing relationships and access to global customer relationships to this joint venture, which will help Pricol to strengthen our leading market position in India," said Vijay Mohan, chairman, Pricol. "Pricol's existing instrument cluster offerings and customer base for motorcycle makers will allow us to enter a new market segment," added DeBest. This new joint venture also will become Johnson Controls' global center of expertise for this product. About Johnson Controls: Johnson Controls is a global diversified technology and industrial leader serving customers in more than 150 countries. Our 162,000 employees create quality products, services and solutions to optimize energy and operational efficiencies of buildings; lead-acid automotive batteries and advanced batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles; and interior systems for automobiles. Our commitment to sustainability dates back to our roots in 1885, with the invention of the first electric room thermostat. Through our growth strategies and by increasing market share we are committed to delivering value to shareholders and making our customers successful. About Johnson Controls Automotive Experience: Johnson Controls is a global leader in automotive seating, overhead systems, door and instrument panels, and interior electronics. We support all major automakers in the differentiation of their vehicles through our products, technologies and advanced manufacturing capabilities. With 240 locations worldwide, we are where our customers need us to be. Consumers have enjoyed the comfort and style of our products, from single components to complete interiors. With our global capability we supply approximately 50 million cars per year. About Pricol: Pricol, which started its operations 35 years ago, is a well-known name in the Indian automotive component sector. Over the last 25 years, Pricol has been a leading supplier of automotive instrument clusters for two wheelers, cars, trucks and tractors in India. The company supports automakers and after-market customers across Europe, America, Middle East and Australasia and supplies instruments and other products including sensors, oil pumps, chain tensioners, fleet management solution products. DOC.TI: Preterm birth risk linked to longer residence in U.S.(WOMEN'S HEALTH)
DOC.TEXT: BY SHARON WORCESTER FROM THE ANNUAL MEETING OF THE SOCIETY FOR MATERNALFETAL MEDICINE DALLAS -- Preterm birth may be related in part to potentially preventable environmental factors, data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) from 1999 through 2006 suggest. Survey responses from 2,441 Hispanic women with a prior live birth show that the rate of births prior to 36 weeks" gestation in Hispanic immigrants who resided in the United States for less than 10 years was 3.1%, which was significantly lower than the 7.4% rate among those who lived in the country for more than 10 years, and the 10.1% rate among Hispanic women born in the United States (age adjusted odds ratios, 2.1 and 3.1, respectively), Dr. Radek Bukowski said at the meeting. The findings were similar after further adjustment for factors that might affect preterm birth risk, such as age, body mass index, education, nutrition, marital status, sexual behaviors, toxic exposures, income, smoking status, diabetes, and hypertension (fully adjusted odds ratios, 2.1 and 3.5), said Dr. Bukowski of the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston. One factor language spoken at home--did appear to have a modifying effect on the association between length of residence in the United States and the risk of preterm birth, however. "Compared with women who lived in the United States less than 10 years, those who lived here 10 years or longer and those who were born in the United States had the highest risk if they predominantly or exclusively spoke Spanish at home," Dr. Bukowski said. Also, body mass index was negatively associated with preterm birth, and hypertension was positively associated with preterm birth, but these were not found to be independent risk factors in the fully adjusted model, he said. Although nongenetic environmental factors have been thought to play a role in preterm birth risk, it has not been clear whether risk is predominantly related to genetic or environmental factors. However, many immigrants are known to have a lower risk, which could be related to better diet and health status, he said. Although limited by the study's cross-sectional design, the current findings suggest that risk is acquired with residence in the United States. Given this, as well as the fact that preterm birth was not associated with a number of other risk factors in this study, it is possible that the level of risk is modifiable, Dr. Bukowski concluded. VITALIS Major Finding: Survey responses from 2,441 Hispanic women with a prior live birth show that the rate of births prior to 36 weeks' gestation in Hispanic immigrants who resided in the United States for less than 10 years was 3.1%, significantly lower than the 7.4% rate among those who lived in the United States for more than 10 years, and the 10.1% rate among Hispanic women born in the United States (age adjusted odds ratios, 2.1 and 3.1, respectively). Data Source: The study involved NHANES data from 1999-2006. Disclosures: Dr. Bukowski said he had no relevant financial disclosures.

DOC.TI: Urate-lowering drugs often underused in gout.(MUSCULOSKELETAL DISORDERS)
DOC.TEXT: SNOWMASS, COLO. -- A disturbing proportion of gout cases are mismanaged, according to one prominent gout expert. "The cause and pathophysiology are well understood, we can make the diagnosis with absolute certainty, and we've got great medicines. Yet today we all see people with tophi. That's tragic. It shouldn't exist." Having a tophus is bad. It's eroding cartilage and bone, and that's something we can prevent if we start urate-lowering therapy soon enough," Dr. Robert L. Wortmann said at the conference. An estimated 8.3 million Americans have gout. Yet, the pharmaceutical industry says 3.1 million of them are prescribed urate-lowering drugs. Five different studies show that 40% of those on allopurinol are prescribed a dose sufficient to drive serum uric acid below 6 mg/dL, which is a key tenet of gout management, noted Dr. Wortmann, professor of medicine at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H. Moreover, poor treatment adherence is a huge problem in gout. A study of close to 4,200 gout patients started on urate-lowering drug therapy found that 56% of them were nonadherent (Arthritis Res. Ther. 2009;11:R46). Dr. Wortmann offered these take home points for managing gout patients: * Don't prescribe urate-lowering drugs for asymptomatic hyperuricemia: This practice hasn't been shown to prevent the future development of gout, yet it exposes patients to the risk of drug toxicities. * But don't ignore asymptomatic hyperuricemia, either: Epidemiologic studies have linked asymptomatic hyperuricemia, defined by a serum urate in excess of 6.8 mg/dL, to increased risks of hypertension, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and all-cause mortality. The big unanswered question is whether using medications to lower serum urate in individuals with asymptomatic hyperuricemia reduces the risk of any of these conditions. That's the subject of ongoing large clinical trials in high-risk patients. If those studies prove positive, clinical practice will change. While awaiting the outcome of the prevention trials, it's worth bearing in mind that Framingham Heart Study data indicate that individuals with a serum uric acid level above 9 mg/dL have a 22% chance of developing gout within the next 5 years. The major contributors to asymptomatic hyperuricemia include obesity, metabolic syndrome, and heavy consumption of fructose-containing beverages or alcohol Those issues should be addressed* Losartan is the only antihypertensive agent that's uricosuric. Fenofibrate is the sole uricosuric drug indicated for dyslipidemia. Preferential consideration could be given to the use of these drugs in hypertensive and/or hyperlipidemic patients with asymptomatic hyperuricemia. * The important thing is not which oral agent you use for treatment of acute gout, it's to initiate therapy as early as possible, at the first hint of an attack. Colchicine, maximum-dose NSAIDs, and oral prednisone dosed at 20 mg BID until symptoms have been gone for 1 week followed by another week at 20 mg/day--they're all effective. And since they work by different mechanisms, they can beneficially be combined in refractory patients. The old-school colchicine dosing regimen most physicians were taught has been cast aside of late. It had a high rate of diarrhea, an "inhumane side effect" in gout patients hobbled by a foot too sore to walk on, Dr. Wortmann said. The former regimen has been replaced by 1.2 mg, given in a single dose, followed by 0.6 mg 1 hour later. "This lower dose is just as effective as the old high-dose regimen of two 0.6-mg pills given at once and then one per hour for the next 5 hours. And the lower-dose program has the same side effect profile as placebo," Dr. Wortmann said. * Get the gout patient's serum urate below 6 mg/dL using the lowest effective dose of the urate-lowering drug you've selected. Physicians have traditionally started gout patients on allopurinol at the standard dose of 300 mg/day. Recently, it has been demonstrated that the risk of developing allopurinol hypersensitivity syndrome is greatly reduced by starting off at 150 mg/day, checking the urate level 2 weeks later, then increasing to 300 mg/day if the serum urate isn't below 6 mg/dL. After 2 weeks at 300 rag/day, check the urate again, and if it still isn't below 6 mg/dL then bump the dose to 400 mg/day. Continue testing and titrating every 2 weeks until the serum urate is less than 6 mg/dL--and preferably less than 4 mg/dL if the patient has tophi--or until the maximum approved dose of 800 mg/day is reached. The same start-low-and-titrate strategy applies to febuxostat, with a maximum approved dose of 80 mg/day. "Check the serum urate after starting therapy, and if it's not below 6 mg/dL, increase the dose," the rheumatologist said. Fortunately, patients who have a hypersensitivity reaction to allopurinol are very unlikely to experience one with febuxostat, and vice versa. For patients who can't reach the target serum urate with maximum-dose therapy, take heart: Second-line agents with impressive potency are well-along in the developmental pipeline. Many labs now list the upper limit of normal for serum urate as 8 mg/dL or 8.5 mg/dL. Dr. Wortmann advised Ignore that ceiling. This raised ceiling is simply the result of the changing demographics among the increasingly obese U.S. population in the last several decades. The definition of asymptomatic hyperuricemia remains unchanged: a serum urate greater than 6.8 mg/dL. And the target in patients with gout is still a serum urate less than 6 mg/dL. Merely dropping a gout patient's urate from 10 to 8 or even 6.6 mg/dL isn't doing any favors; the disease will continue to progress if the urate is above 6 mg/dL. * All gout is tophaceous. Even if tophi aren't apparent on clinical examination, often they are radiographically. "This is a message that has to get out," Dr. Wortmann insisted. Gout management guidelines proposed by the American College of Rheumatology call for starting urate-lowering drug therapy when a patient is experiencing three attacks per year. Dr. Wortmann takes issue with that. "I would argue that once you've had a third attack of gout, period, you should be treated. Maybe even sooner. We need to prevent the erosion and bony destruction that occur with tophi," he said. One audience member complained that his gout patients with comorbid renal insufficiency and/or cardiovascular disease often get caught in a revolving door. He titrates their allopurinol to an effective dose, but when they are later admitted to the hospital because of their comorbid conditions the hospitalists, nephrologists, or cardiologists are shocked at the allopurinol dose and either reduce it or stop it altogether. After discharge and return home, the patient eventually reappears in his office with active gout. He then resumes their allopurinol at the previous dose, and they remain well controlled until the next hospitalization, when the same thing happens. Urate-lowering therapy is not a one-size-fits-all matter, Dr. Wortmann said. To get rid of gout, it's necessary to drive the serum urate to the target of less than 6 mg/dL. This will be accomplished by using the lowest effective dose. He reported serving as a consultant to Savient, Takeda, URL Pharmaceuticals, Novartis, and Ardea Biosciences. BY BRUCE JANCIN EXPERT ANALYSIS FROM A SYMPOSIUM SPONSORED BY THE AMERICAN COLLEGE OF RHEUMATOLOGY

DOC.TI: ALK-Abello to book EUR 3.2m gain on French DBV listing
DOC.TEXT: (SeeNews) - Mar 30, 2012 - Danish pharma company ALK-Abello A/S (CPH:ALK B) said Thursday it will book in the first quarter of 2012 a capital gain of DKK 24 million (USD 4.3m/EUR 3.2m) after the stock listing of its associated company, French DBV Technologies (EPA:DBV). The French biotechnology group debuted yesterday on Euronext Paris, raising EUR 40 million (USD 53.4m) in its initial public offering (IPO), which was settled at EUR 8.86 apiece. As ALK-Abello did not participate in the offering, its shareholding in DBV, which specialises in food allergy, was reduced to 6%. ALK-Abello reiterated its guidance for earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of over DKK 300 million for 2012.
